div.head: Introduction
div.p: Many of our decisions are guided by imperfect information about latent variables that govern our experiences. For example, to infer the quality of a restaurant, we must learn about it by trying different dishes. While doing so, small differences in the experienced quality can be written off as expected fluctuations around a baseline quality. However, unexpectedly large deviations could indicate that the quality has systematically changed, for example, because the restaurant has a new chef. In such a case, it may be necessary to update our beliefs more dramatically (and consider eating at a different restaurant). Attributing outcomes to variability or change points can be difficult in the face of uncertainty but is critical for controlling the degree to which new experiences should influence learning. Doing so effectively is crucial for adaptive behavior across the human lifespan, but on the other hand, doing so perfectly is computationally challenging and, in many situations, completely infeasible.

Previous work has identified normative mechanisms derived from principles of optimal Bayesian inference for implementing this sort of belief updating (Behrens, Woolrich, Walton, & Rushworth, 2007;Meyniel & Dehaene, 2017;O'Reilly et al., 2013;Payzan-LeNestour, Dunne, Bossaerts, & O'Doherty, 2013). However, humans seem to deviate systematically from optimal behavior, raising questions as to whether they might rely on computationally cheaper alternatives. Computationally frugal strategies for approximating optimal inference may be resource rational in the sense that they demand less cognitive resources while ensuring a reasonable level of performance (Gigerenzer & Gaissmaier, 2011;Simon, 1955Simon, , 1956Lieder & Griffiths, 2020).

The need for computationally inexpensive solutions might be particularly high when cognitive resources are limited, for example, during childhood when the relevant brain circuits are not yet fully developed or later in life when cognitive abilities are starting to diminish. Children and older adults often show performance deficits relative to young adults across a wide range of cognitive tasks (Chowdhury et al., 2013;De Boer et al., 2017;Eppinger, Kray, Mock, & Mecklinger, 2008;Eppinger, Mock, & Kray, 2009;Eppinger, Schuck, Nystrom, & Cohen, 2013;Hämmerer, Li, Müller, & Lindenberger, 2011;Hämmerer et al., 2019;Rutledge et al., 2009;Samanez-Larkin, Kuhnen, Yoo, & Knutson, 2010;Samanez-Larkin, Levens, Perry, Dougherty, & Knutson, 2012;Samanez-Larkin, Worthy, Mata, McClure, & Knutson, 2014;Van den Bos, Cohen, Kahnt, & Crone, 2012;Van der Schaaf, Warmerdam, Crone, & Cools, 2011). In typical decision-making and cognitive control tasks, these age groups often perseverate on previous responses Blackwell, Chatham, Wiseheart, & Munakata, 2014;Carroll, Blakey, & FitzGibbon, 2016;Cepeda & Munakata, 2007;Crone, Jennings, & Van der Molen, 2004;Crone, Ridderinkhof, Worm, Somsen, & van der Molen, 2004;Head, Kennedy, Rodrigue, & Raz, 2009;Munakata, Snyder, & Chatham, 2012;Ridderinkhof, Span, & Van Der Molen, 2002;Rutledge et al., 2009). Conversely, when such tasks provide additional task-related cues, children and older adults show an over-reliance on available external cues or anchors (Alarcón & Bonardi, 2020;Chatham, Frank, & Munakata, 2009;Craik & Bialystok, 2006;Gonthier, Zira, Colé, & Blaye, 2019;Lindenberger & Mayr, 2014;Munakata et al., 2012;Troller-Renfree, Buzzell, & Fox, 2020). Despite considerable lifespan developmental research on these topics, there is no satisfying computational account for why people are prone to these biases early and late in life.

Here, we examine the possibility that perseveration and anchoring biases across the human lifespan might result from computationally frugal belief-updating strategies calibrated to minimize cognitive resource expenditure. In particular, we propose that instead of incurring the total computational cost to update beliefs optimally, individuals approximate optimal inference by drawing "samples" from the Bayesian belief distribution (Daw & Courville, 2007;Gershman & Beck, 2017;Sanborn, 2017;Sanborn & Chater, 2016;Vul, Goodman, Griffiths, & Tenenbaum, 2014;Dasgupta, Schulz, & Gershman, 2017;Lieder, Griffiths, Huys, & Goodman, 2018). With sufficient samples, such a strategy approximates optimal inference. However, satisfactory predictions might be achieved with even a very small number of samples, presenting a trade-off between the accuracy of beliefs and the computational cost of updating them. For instance, imagine a person thinking about a restaurant's quality after trying out a new dish (Fig. 1a). To compute her belief about the quality, she could mentally draw samples approximating the optimal belief distribution (Fig. 1b). The sampling process would start from some initial value, such as the previous belief about the restaurant, and drift through different hypothetical beliefs. This could be considered a chain of thoughts where the decision-maker sequentially considers different potential beliefs about the restaurant. To minimize computational cost, the person might stop sampling when a criterion value of accuracy is reached.

We argue that differences in learning biases across the lifespan emerge because changes in cognitive resources across development shift the trade-off between the benefits and costs of sampling. When a previous belief is deemed accurate enough, it gives rise to perseveration, thereby saving cognitive resources (Fig. 1b, left). Similarly, when updating beliefs from an external anchor, an individual who tries to minimize resources may be more easily satisfied with only a small number of samples, leading to beliefs that are closer to the initial anchor (anchoring bias; Fig. 1b, right). From this perspective, it would be a rational strategy for children and older adults to integrate the costs and benefits of sampling. Thereby, they would rely on fewer samples compared to younger adults, which naturally amplifies their learning biases ( Fig. 1c,d).

In the present study, we examine whether differences in learning across the lifespan emerge from efficient belief-updating mechanisms, taking into account the amount of cognitive re-sources that should be allocated to learning. We combine computational modeling with two age-comparative experiments using a predictive inference task. In the first experiment, beliefs were updated directly from their previous values. Assuming lower cognitive resources in children and older adults, a sampling model of belief updating predicts more perseveration in these groups compared to adolescents and younger adults. In line with this prediction, performance differences between age groups resulted from more perseveration in children and older adults than in adolescents and younger adults. In the second experiment, we built upon these results and manipulated the starting position from which participants had to update their predictions by providing external anchors. Here, a sampling model predicts that external anchors lead to greater anchoring biases in children and older adults. Consistent with this prediction, we found stronger anchoring biases in children and older adults compared to younger adults. Across participants, we show that greater levels of perseveration are associated with greater anchoring biases, consistent with our model's assumption that perseveration and anchoring originate from a common sampling mechanism. Taken together, our study suggests that perseveration and anchoring biases share a common cause, can emerge from a computationally frugal belief updating strategy, and are amplified in children and older adults in a manner consistent with resource rationality.

div.head: Participants
div.p: For the first experiment, we recruited 33 children, 31 adolescents, 35 younger adults, and 37 older adults from the participant pools of the Chair of Lifespan Developmental Neuroscience at Technische Universität Dresden, with participants recruited from the Dresden community. Due to errors in the data acquisition, we excluded 2 adolescents and older adults and 3 younger adults. The effective study sample consisted of 33 children (8 to 10 years, median age 9.0 years, 19 female), 29 adolescents (13 to 17 years, median age 15.0 years, 11 female), 32 younger adults (20 to 28 years, median age 24.0 years, 15 female), and 35 older adults (62 to 80 years, median age 71.0 years, 7 female). For the follow-up experiment, we recruited 34 children, 29 younger adults, and 38 older adults from the Max Planck Institute for Human Development Berlin participant pool. Due to errors in the data acquisition, we excluded 3 children and 4 younger and older adults. Here the effective study sample thus comprised 31 children (7 to 11 years, median age 9.0 years, 12 female), 25 younger adults (20 to 28 years, median age 24.0 years, 16 female), and 34 older adults (61 to 76 years, median age 67.0 years, 25 female). To compare basic psychometric profiles across our data sets and to previous work, we measured the participants' processing speed and verbal knowledge using the Identical Picture and Spot-a-Word test . The sample size was chosen based on our recent age-comparative work on learning using comparable methods . In both experiments, we obtained written informed consent from the younger and older adults. Moreover, we obtained written informed consent from the children and adolescents and their parents. The experimental protocol was approved by the institutional review board of Technische Universität Dresden ("Die Entwicklung habitueller und zielgerichteter Lern-und Entscheidungsprozesse über die Lebensspanne", protocol number: EK 276072013) and by the institutional review board of the Max Planck Institute for Human Development Berlin ("Age differences in goal-directed learning and decision making across the lifespan"). This study was not preregistered.

div.head: Experimental task
div.p: We begin with an intuitive description of the task and the experimental conditions that we applied in the first and the follow-up experiment. After that, we provide a formal description of the task structure. The task was framed in an intuitive cover story, in which a helicopter dropped bags that had to be caught by participants ( Fig. 2a). Because clouds covered the sky, participants could not observe the helicopter directly, but they were required to infer the helicopter's position based on the previously dropped bags. Participants used a bucket that could be moved around via button presses to catch the bags (Prediction) using separate keys for fast movements (left: F, right: J) and slow movements (left: G, right: H). After participants had placed their buckets, they could not be adjusted anymore. Subsequently, the hidden helicopter dropped a bag (Outcome). After that, a red line indicated the prediction error, defined as the distance between the actual and predicted location of the bag (Prediction Error). Finally, participants updated their prediction of the next outcome (Update) and transitioned to the next trial.

The hidden helicopter represented the mean of a Gaussian distribution that generated the outcomes (Fig. 2b). The standard deviation of this distribution determined the amount of variability across outcomes, framed as wind in the cover story. As a consequence, bags mostly appeared left or right to the helicopter. Occasionally, the helicopter moved to a different location (change point). Therefore, the challenge in the task was the distinction between (i) systematic changes and (ii) random influences (risk). A prediction error could thus be due to (i) a change point, which should optimally result in a considerable adjustment of the bucket towards the most recent outcome, or (ii) random variability in the outcomes attributable to risk, which should lead to more subtle bucket adjustments. Only on a few trials, when the helicopter was visible, could participants distinguish change points and random variability to adjust their predictions to the mean of the outcome-generating distribution (we refer to these trials as "catch trials" in the following). Before performing the helicopter task, participants underwent a training session described in SM Task instructions.

div.head: First experiment
div.p: In the first experiment, we used two conditions that differed in the amount of variability across outcomes. In the first condition, bags were only weakly corrupted by the wind. Consequently, change points could more easily be distinguished from random variability. In contrast, in the second, the wind was stronger, and change points were harder to detect. These conditions were completed across four alternating task blocks, and the order of the conditions was counterbalanced between participants. Approximately half of the participants started with the low-variability condition, and the other half started with the high-variability condition. Since participants show smaller updates in the high-compared to the low-variability condition, this manipulation helped reduce the correlation between prediction errors and updates within participants . Moreover, in the high-variability condition, participants achieve less accurate predictions compared to the low-variability condition. To match the achieved performance across conditions, we increased the bucket size in the second one. Moreover, bags randomly contained gold coins or stones. The number of collected gold coins was translated into monetary reward at the end of the task, but collected stones were not rewarded. Participants were instructed that gold and stone bags were dropped by the same helicopter. However, note that whether the bags contained gold or rocks was only revealed after the bag was dropped. Consequently, to maximize the amount of reward, the best strategy was to try to catch every bag independently of what it might contain. The reward structure of the task was explicitly communicated to the participants. Additionally, for approximately half the participants, we inverted the reward value to control for potential saliency effects of the color associated with bag content. Here, rewarding bags were labeled as silver bags and neutral bags as sandbags, respectively. We included the reward manipulation to test if irrelevant reward information systematically affects participants' learning behavior (McGuire, Nassar, Gold, & Kable, 2014;Sharot & Garrett, 2016;Lefebvre, Lebreton, Meyniel, Bourgeois-Gironde, & Palminteri, 2017). Finally, the task was designed to minimize the contribution of working memory differences between the age groups to learning behavior. On each trial, we displayed the participants' previous prediction error using a red line at the bottom of the screen. At the ends of the prediction-error line, we presented tick marks that explicitly indicated the previous prediction and the previous outcome. This was done to allow participants to use this information to update their current predictions. In the instructions, we explicitly stated that the participants should update their prediction so that it falls within the range of the displayed prediction error.

Follow-up experiment In the follow-up experiment, our goal was to examine the influence of the starting location of the updating process and the reward associated with catching a bag on perseveration and estimation errors ( Fig. 4a). First, in the "anchoring" condition, we manipulated the starting location of updates acting as an external anchor by replacing the initial position of the bucket. To do so, we used a Gaussian distribution with a mean equal to the previous bucket position to sample the starting position of the bucket randomly. Second, to examine the influence of reward magnitude on perseveration and anchoring, we indicated the bag content throughout the trial. This was done by displaying a '+' symbol above the bucket, which was presented in gold (for gold coins, high reward) or gray (for stones, low reward). To focus on the two above-described manipulations, we kept the amount of variability in the outcomes constant and used a variability level equal to the mean of the two conditions of the first experiment. This version of the task was divided into four task blocks (for all participants, block 1 and 3: anchoring condition; block 2 and 4: standard condition without externally provided anchor). Finally, as in the first experiment, we explicitly showed the trial-by-trial prediction errors using the red line and tick marks. Hence, in both experiments, participants had access to the same information about outcomes and predictions, and the key difference was the starting location of the prediction.

Formal description A short note on the notation (Bruckner, Heekeren, & Ostwald, 2019;Ostwald, Bruckner, & Heekeren, 2018): We divide the formal documentation of our analyses into a task model, the description of the computational models, and the steps to evaluate and estimate the models based on behavioral data. We follow the conventions of applied probabilistic modeling, i.e., we do not explicitly distinguish between probability distributions, probability density functions, or probability mass functions. Moreover, we indicate parameters by superscripts.
• T := 100 denotes the number of trials for each of the four task blocks, indexed as t = 1, 2, ..., T ,
• X ∈ [0, 300] denotes the set of outcomes x in the task,
• M ∈ [0, 300] is the set of the mean parameters µ of the Gaussian distribution that generates the outcomes and that corresponds to the helicopter location in the cover story,

• S ∈ N >0 is the set of standard-deviation parameters of the Gaussian distribution that generates the outcomes, where, in the first experiment, we have σ = 10 (condition 1, less windy environment) and σ = 25 (condition 2, more windy environment) and in the follow-up experiment σ = 17.5,

• C ∈ {0, 1} is the set of change points in the outcome contingencies, where c t = 0 denotes that outcome contingencies are unchanged, and c t = 1 indicates a change point in the outcome contingencies,

• R ∈ {0, 1} refers to the set of rewards in the task, where, in the first experiment, we used r t = 0 for no-reward trials and r t = 1 for high-reward trials; in the follow-up experiment, we used r t = 0 for low-reward and r t = 1 for high-reward trials,
• V ∈ {0, 1} refers to the set of helicopter-visibility trial types , where v t = 0 denotes that the helicopter was hidden and v t = 1 denotes that the helicopter was visible ("catch trials"),
• B ∈ [0, 300] denotes the set of predictions b,
• Z ∈ [0, 300] denotes the set of initial bucket locations z in the follow-up experiment,

div.head: Data preprocessing
div.p: Additional variables of interest for the analyses were participants' estimation errors, prediction errors, prediction updates, and perseveration trials. In the follow-up experiment, we were additionally interested in the external anchors determining the starting location of the bucket with which participants caught the bags dropped by the helicopter.
• D ∈ [−300, 300] refers to the set of prediction errors, defined as δ t :
div.formula: = x t − b t ,
div.p: • E ∈ [0, 300] is the set of estimation errors, defined as e t := |µ t − b t |, i.e., the absolute distance between the helicopter location and the prediction,
• A ∈ [−300, 300] refers to the set of trial-by-trial prediction updates, which are defined as,
div.formula: a t := b t+1 − b t ,
div.p: • N ∈ {0, 1} refers to the set of perseveration trials, defined as n t := 1, a t = 0 0, otherwise, i.e., trials in which predictions were not updated were categorized as perseveration trials,
• N * ∈ {0, 1} refers to the set of trials in which participants directly locked in their prediction at the initial bucket location (motor perseveration). Motor perseveration was defined as

• Y ∈ [−300, 300] refers to the shift of the external anchor relative to the prior prediction, defined by y t := z t+1 − b t .

div.head: Average learning-rate analysis
div.p: We used a regression model to compute average learning rates. The model describes learning behavior according to principles of error-driven learning. In particular, the model explains the update a t as a function of the prediction error δ t , like in classical reinforcement-learning models (Daw, 2014). In the first experiment, the regression model was defined by
div.formula: a t = β 0 + β 1 δ t ,(1)
div.p: where β 0 denotes the intercept of the model, and the slope β 1 can be interpreted as the average learning rate (typically denoted by α in the field of reinforcement learning) that determines the overall influence of the prediction error δ t on the update a t . In the follow-up experiment, we additionally took into consideration the external anchor, i.e., the shift in the bucket location y t :
div.formula: a t = β 0 + β 1 δ t + β 2 y t .(2)
div.p: To estimate the free parameters, we used ordinary least squares from the statsmodels OLS class in Python.

div.head: Robust regression
div.p: In the follow-up experiment, we computed the association between perseveration in the standard helicopter task and the anchoring bias in the anchoring condition using the robust linear regression model
div.formula: d i = β 0 + β 1p (n) i (3)
div.p: where d i denotes the anchoring bias of participant i, β 0 denotes the intercept of the regression model, and β 1 the regression weight ofp(n) i , i.e., the estimated perseveration probability of participant i. In Fig. 5d, the points show d i as a function ofp(n) i , and the line shows the predicted values according to the robust regression model (see also SM Robust regression with age group). We estimated the model using robust regression from statsmodels in Python.

div.head: Reduced Bayesian model
div.p: The experimental task can be solved using a Bayesian change-point-detection algorithm that predicts future outcomes based on all previous outcomes . This solution requires considering all possible combinations of change points (see SM Optimal and approximate inference). However, given the unrealistic assumption that humans similarly rely on the memory of all previous trials during learning, Nassar and colleagues proposed a reduced learning model that approximates this algorithm Nassar et al., 2012;Wilson et al., 2010).

In the reduced Bayesian model, the learning-rate regulation depends on relative uncertainty, change-point probability, and the hazard rate. Relative uncertainty indicates the uncertainty of the model's belief about the helicopter location based on the history of outcomes relative to the variability in the environment. When the model has only observed a few outcomes, relative uncertainty tends to be higher and subsequently declines with each new observation (Fig. 2b). After a change point, the previously learned helicopter estimate is not predictive of future outcomes anymore. Therefore, the best strategy is to restart the estimation of the helicopter position. However, because the model cannot directly observe change points, it keeps track of change-point probability, which indicates the probability of a change point based on the most recently observed outcome (Fig. 2b). Change-point probability itself depends on the hazard-rate parameter, which reflects the model's assumption about the rate of change in the environment. That is, with a subjectively higher hazard-rate parameter, the model assumes more change points throughout the task. The learning rate is a weighted combination of relative uncertainty and change-point probability (Fig. 2b). When change-point probability is high, more recent outcomes have a greater impact on learning, whereas more distant outcomes are forgotten. When change-point probability is low, learning is mostly driven by relative uncertainty, and the model more strongly considers multiple previous outcomes.
In contrast to the task model, µ t (i.e., helicopter location) is unknown to the model and has to be learned throughout the task. Here
• µ 0 := 150 is the model's initial estimate of the µ parameter,
• σ 2 0 := 100 is the model's initial estimation uncertainty over the µ parameter,
• u ∈ R ≥0 is the uncertainty-underestimation parameter, indicating the extent to which estimation uncertainty is underestimated (u = 0 if the model does not underestimate uncertainty),
• h ∈ [0, 1] is the subjective hazard-rate parameter that models participants' assumptions about the overall probability of a change point,

• s ∈ [0, 1] is the surprise-sensitivity parameter that indicates the degree to which changepoint probability influences the learning rate; hence, higher values indicate a stronger influence of change-point probability on learning (s = 1 if the model does not have a reduced surprise sensitivity),
• µ H is the true location of the helicopter that is only revealed on catch trials,

• σ H ∈ N >0 is a free parameter that models the standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution of the perceptual information provided by the visible helicopter (σ H = 0 if the model perfectly considers catch trials),

• q ∈ [−1, 1] is a free parameter (in the first experiment) that determines the degree to which the reward type of the previous trial modulates the learning rate (q = 0 if the model is not influenced by reward), and finally,
• d ∈ R is the free anchoring-bias parameter (in the follow-up experiment) that models the influence of the anchor magnitude y t on the belief update (d = 0 if the anchor does not bias the model).
To infer the µ t+1 parameter, the reduced Bayesian model combines the latest outcome x t and the previous prediction µ t . This combination is achieved using an error-driven sequential updating rule
div.formula: µ t+1 := µ t +â t ,(4)
div.p: whereâ
div.formula: t := α t δ t(5)
div.p: and where
div.formula: δ t := x t − µ t(6)
div.p: refers to the prediction error that expresses the difference between the last outcome x t and the last prediction µ t . The weight of this combination is determined by the learning rate α t . The reduced Bayesian model uses a dynamical learning rate that depends on the two factors change-point probability ω t and relative uncertainty τ t :
div.formula: α t := ω t + τ t − τ t ω t .(7)
div.p: Change-point probability ω t is computed as a function of the current prediction error δ t , the assumed hazard rate h, the total uncertainty about the next outcome, and the degree of surprise sensitivity s, i.e.,
Next, to determine relative uncertainty τ t+1 for the next trial, the model first computes estimation uncertainty about the helicopter position, defined as
div.formula: σ 2 t+1 := ω t σ 2 + (1 − ω t )τ t σ 2 + ω t (1 − ω t )(δ t (1 − τ t )) 2 exp(u) ,(9)
div.p: where the u parameter determines the degree of uncertainty underestimation. Subsequently, the model computes the fraction of estimation uncertainty relative to its total uncertainty about the next outcome, which is the sum of estimation uncertainty and the variability or risk in the environment σ 2 :

When the helicopter was occasionally presented, we assumed that participants would partially consider the additional information to adjust their helicopter estimate and the associated estimation uncertainty (see SM Catch-trial derivations). On catch trials, the inferred helicopter location was a combination of the previously learned helicopter position and the true helicopter location
div.formula: µ t+1 = (1 − w t )µ t+1 + w t µ H ,(11)
div.p: where
div.formula: w t := σ 2 t σ 2 t + σ 2 H ,(12)
div.p: and where σ 2 H models to which degree the reduced Bayesian model trusts the helicopter information (i.e., higher σ 2 H leads to a lower consideration of catch trials). Relative uncertainty was subsequently adjusted to incorporate the additional information provided by the visible helicopter
div.formula: τ t = C C + σ 2(13)
div.p: where

Moreover, to model a reward-driven learning-rate bias in trials in which the previous reward was high (r t−1 = 1, in the first experiment; McGuire et al., 2014), we added the value of the freely estimated reward-bias parameter to the learning rate (α t + q) and for all α t > 1 and α t < 0, adjusted the learning rate to α t = 1 and α t = 0, respectively.
Finally, in the follow-up experiment, we implemented the anchoring bias d in the following way:â
div.formula: t =â t + dy t .(15)

div.head: Perseveration model
div.p: To model perseveration, we used the Dirac-delta function δ(a t ) = 1, a t = 0 0, otherwise

according to which perseveration probability is 0 everywhere except at 0, where it is 1. As described in the following section, we combined this perseveration model with the reduced Bayesian model, and we estimated the contribution of each model to updating behavior for each participant. In Fig. S4, we illustrate the mixture model combining the perseveration model and the reduced Bayesian model.

div.head: Evaluation and estimation
div.p: We evaluated and estimated the mixture model using participants' prediction errors. That is, instead of computing a prediction error as the difference between the actual outcome x t and the learned µ t parameter of the reduced Bayesian model (see eq. (6)), we used the actual prediction errors of our participants as described in Data preprocessing. Using the participants' prediction errors is advantageous over model-based prediction errors because participant and model predictions might occasionally deviate from each other. Next to the free parameters described above, we estimated the following parameters:
• o 0 ∈ N >0 is the motor-noise parameter, modeling noise in the placement of the bucket,
• o 1 ∈ N >0 is the learning-rate noise parameter that accounts for increasing noise as a function of the required update magnitude,
• b 0 ∈ N is the intercept of the logistic function that determined the mixture weight between the learning and perseveration component,
• b 1 ∈ N is the slope of the same logistic function.
To evaluate the probability of the current update, we used a Gaussian distribution
div.formula: p εt (a t |x 1:T ) := N (a t ;â t , ε 2 t )(17)
div.p: where

The rationale behind the motor-noise parameter o 0 and learning-rate noise parameter o 1 is that participants' reported belief updates are noisy to a certain extent. We decomposed updating noise into two different components. Motor noise reflects imprecision of the motor system (i.e., finger movements in our case), and learning-rate noise captures that larger updates tend to be more noisy than smaller updates. Thus, the ε t parameter in eq. (18) reflects a combination of these two noise components. Accordingly, trial-by-trial updates are defined to be sampled from a Gaussian distribution with mean equal to the model-predicted update a t and standard deviation ε t capturing updating noise (eq. (17)).

Next, eq. (17) reflects the predictions of the reduced Bayesian model. In order to combine the predictions of the reduced Bayesian model and the perseveration model, we developed a mixture model between the two. Specifically, the mixture between the probability of the learning component (reduced Bayesian model) and the probability of the perseveration component (perseveration model) was determined by
div.formula: p λt,δ (a t |x 1:T ) := λ t δ(a t ) + (1 − λ t )p εt (a t |x 1:T ),(19)
div.p: where

Here, we assumed that trials with an update equal to zero could be due to the learning component or the perseveration component (where the higher the absolute predicted update of the reduced Bayesian model, the lower the probability that the trial was generated by the perseveration component). In contrast, for trials where participants did not perseverate, we assumed that data were exclusively generated by the learning component. The mixture between the two components was modeled using a logistic function with parameters b 0 and b 1 . The intercept b 0 indicates the function's midpoint, and the slope b 1 models the steepness. For an illustration, we refer to Fig. S4.

We estimated the free parameters using the constrained minimization algorithm L-BFGS-B from the Python SciPy optimize framework. We repeated the estimation 10 times using randomly determined starting points and selected the parameters of the iteration that achieved the best fit to the data, i.e., the lowest negative log-likelihood. To ensure reproducible results, we used the same fixed value of the random seed for all analyses. Finally, consistent with our previous study , we used a weakly informative Gaussian prior with mean 0 and standard deviation 5 to regularize the estimation of the uncertainty-underestimation parameter.

div.head: Model comparison
div.p: To test if the mixture model between the reduced Bayesian model and the perseveration model describes the data better than the control model without perseveration, we compared the cumulated Bayesian information criterion (BIC; and the corresponding protected exceedance probabilities . The BIC for each participant was defined as
div.formula: BIC := − k 2 ln(T )(21)
div.p: where denotes the maximum log-likelihood, k the number of free parameters, and T the number of trials.

div.head: Sampling model
div.p: The sampling model translates the reduced Bayesian model described above to a sampling algorithm combined with a stopping criterion determining when the sampling process stops and the model commits to a belief update. We first give a brief introduction to Markov Chain Monte-Carlo (MCMC) sampling and then provide a formal description of our own sampling model. MCMC is a popular method for estimating posterior distributions in Bayesian inference (van Ravenzwaaij, Cassey, & Brown, 2018). A key challenge in Bayesian inference is computing integrals to obtain the posterior of a model. For example, optimal predictions of outcomes in the helicopter task can be computed using Bayes' rule
div.formula: p(µ t |x 1:t ) = p(x 1:t |µ t )p(µ t ) p(x 1:t |µ t )p(µ t )dµ t ,(22)
div.p: where µ t denotes the helicopter position and x 1:t denotes the observed outcomes (for more details, see SM Optimal and approximate Bayesian inference). The primary computational challenge for implementing a Bayesian solution is to compute the integral in the denominator since doing so requires not only evaluating the likelihood with which a single hypothetical mean might give rise to the data but also evaluating the likelihood of all possible means. While for the helicopter task, computationally costly analytical solutions exist , evaluating the posterior analytically is entirely intractable in many other cases. Monte Carlo strategies, such as rejection sampling, provide means for approximating Bayesian solutions without the need to evaluate the costly integral by selecting samples from a proposal distribution and "accepting" samples according to their un-normalized probability. Such methods can cut computational costs by requiring only the evaluation of the numerator of eq. (22). However, an issue is that these methods can be computationally costly if the proposal distribution deviates substantially from the true underlying target distribution being inferred.

Markov Chain Monte-Carlo (MCMC) extends basic Monte-Carlo methods such that the proposal distribution (i.e., hypotheses about helicopter position that one might consider) evolves over time and depends on the most recent sample in a growing chain . The advantage of this strategy over full Bayesian solutions is that it does not require evaluating the integral in the denominator of Bayes rule, and the advantage over static Monte-Carlo methods is that since the chain of samples will evolve toward the target distribution, the proposal distribution will efficiently sample the space of likely hypotheses (i.e., helicopter positions that could have given rise to data). In broad strokes, the MCMC strategy approximates the posterior distribution by iteratively performing two steps: (i) draw a proposed sample from a proposal distribution centered on the last sample in the chain, and (ii) evaluate the un-normalized posterior probability of the sample and either accept the sample (add it to the chain) or reject it accordingly. When computing the approximate posterior, we build a chain of many samples that are accepted in the chain according to their un-normalized posterior distribution analogous to the numerator in eq. (22) ("target distribution"). Over time, these samples form a pattern that reflects the true distribution of the helicopter location, and the more samples that are generated in this way, the better the estimate tends to be.

One way to perform MCMC sampling is using the Metropholis-Hastings algorithm . To illustrate the sampling process of the helicopter location based on this algorithm, we enumerate the different steps (van Ravenzwaaij et al., 2018).
1. Begin with a starting value. The sampling process starts from an initial value, such as the last prediction or an external anchor.

div.head: Propose a new sample.
div.p: A new sample is drawn from a proposal distribution that often corresponds to a Gaussian probability distribution. Each new sample from this proposal distribution can be interpreted as a hypothesis about the true but unknown helicopter location. The mean of the proposal distribution is equal to the last sample.

3. Compute acceptance probability. Compute the probability of accepting the proposed sample. This is based on how likely the newly proposed hypothetical helicopter location is under the un-normalized target distribution of the actual helicopter location compared to the most recent sample. For example, the target distribution might be a Gaussian with a mean of 180 and a standard deviation of 20. The algorithm would then compare the probability density of the proposed sample N (160; 180, 20) to the most recent sample N (150; 180, 20). It is accepted if the new sample is more likely (like in the example). If it is less likely, it will be accepted with a probability that is proportional to how much less likely it is.
4. Decide to accept or reject the proposed sample. The proposed sample is accepted according to the previously computed acceptance probability.

5. Repeat sampling and decide when to stop. Repeat steps 2 through 4 to generate a large number of samples. Given certain conditions and enough time, the chain of samples will represent samples from the true helicopter distribution. The total number of samples is typically chosen beforehand. In our own sampling model described below, the number of samples is chosen online and differs from trial to trial.

6. Use samples for inference. Once the posterior distribution over the helicopter location is approximated based on the samples, one can estimate properties of the distribution, such as the mean (most likely helicopter location) or variance (uncertainty about helicopter location).

Our own sampling model assumes that humans rely on sampling to approximate optimal belief updating under consideration of their cognitive resources (Lieder et al., 2018;Sanborn & Chater, 2016;Sanborn, 2017;Vul et al., 2014). As explained above, each sample can be interpreted as a specific hypothesis about the helicopter location, and drawing more samples would more closely approximate the posterior distribution of the helicopter. However, at the same time, each sample represents a limited resource, and from a resource-rationality perspective, the benefits and costs of sampling should determine how much to sample. Therefore, we combined the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm sketched above with a dynamic stopping criterion determining when the sampling process is terminated (Fig. 6a). To do so, the model draws a certain number of samples (determined by the chunk-size parameter) and evaluates whether the new set of samples has improved the belief (governed by the stopping criterion). This evaluation is based on a comparison of the un-normalized posterior probability of the sample distribution's mean, both with and without the additional chunk of samples. If the new samples do not sufficiently boost the un-normalized posterior probability (evaluated at the mean of all samples in the chain), the model rejects them, terminates the sampling process, and uses the mean of the previously sampled values as its new belief. In contrast, if the new chunk of samples increases the unnormalized posterior probability of the belief considerably, the sampling process is continued. That is, the model would generate another chunk of samples and again evaluate whether the sampling process can be terminated or an additional set of samples is required. The next section explains the two parameters in more detail.
1. Chunk-size parameter. The chunk size determines how many samples one can draw per unit of time and can be interpreted as the available amount of cognitive resources.
Here, the idea is that people with more cognitive resources can generate more samples per chunk. Consequently, each chunk would include more samples, thereby being more accurate.

2. Stopping criterion. The stopping criterion governs at what point the sampling process stops, which can be interpreted as the willingness to invest resources. Here, the idea is that it is necessary to keep on sampling as long as more samples improve the accuracy of the belief. However, when new samples do not improve belief accuracy further, the model stops, thereby saving cognitive resources. Stopping is achieved by comparing the un-normalized posterior probability of the mean of the sample distribution with and without the new chunk of samples. For example, the target distribution might have a mean of 180. If the mean of the samples, including the new chunk is 170, and without the new samples, 165, then the new samples have improved belief accuracy, and the model would continue the sampling process. Intuitively, when the sample mean converges on the mean of the target density, the belief cannot be further improved, and thus sampling would stop. While one could imagine the conservative policy of stopping only when new samples provide exactly zero improvement, such a policy would require drawing a lot of samples. A more frugal strategy would be to set some criterion level of improvement that is required to continue sampling, with a level of improvement below this threshold indicating that the belief based on prior samples is good enough. This idea is often referred to as "satisficing" (Simon, 1955(Simon, , 1956. Therefore, the stopping criterion governs at what point an individual decides that drawing new samples is unnecessary. A lower, more conservative stopping criterion (≈ 0) indicates that the two beliefs have to be virtually the same, while more liberal values (> 0) would indicate that a minor difference between the two beliefs would be tolerated, in line with the idea of satisficing.

The basic Metropolis-Hastings algorithm combined with the chunk size and stopping criterion yields perseveration and anchoring in the following way: Perseveration takes place when the model rejects the first chunk of samples (the accuracy of the hypothetical belief based on the new samples is not sufficiently better than the prior belief). Anchoring, on the other hand, takes place when an external anchor determines the start location of the sampling process, and the model draws a limited amount of samples that do not fully compensate for the anchor.
More formally, the model is represented by the following parameters and distributions.
• x ∈ R denotes the set of samples drawn by the model, where we particularly distinguish the most recent sample x new from the previous sample x curr ,
• σ mh := 30 denotes the standard deviation of the sampling distribution,
div.formula: • q(x new |x curr ) := N (x new ; x curr , σ 2 mh )
div.p: is the Gaussian proposal distribution generating the samples,
div.formula: • p * prior (x) := N (x; µ t , σ 2 t )
div.p: denotes the Gaussian distribution for the model's prior belief about the latent helicopter location µ t ,
div.formula: • p * lik (x t ) := N (x t , x, σ 2 )
div.p: is the likelihood of the outcome x t given sample x,
• p * post (x) is the posterior belief distribution,
• n refers to the sample-chunk size, and finally,
• c is the stopping criterion.

On each trial, the model samples according to the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm . At each sampling step, a new sample is generated from the Gaussian proposal distribution q(x new |x curr ), where x new denotes the generated sample conditional on the current sample x curr and the sample variance σ 2 mh . The model probabilistically accepts and rejects a new sample based on the ratio of the new and current sample with respect to the target distribution p * post (x):
div.formula: r mh = min(1, p * post (x new ) p * post (x curr ) ).(23)
div.p: That is, when x new is more likely, the model accepts the new sample, but if it is less likely, the acceptance probability is equal to the relative probabilities (mh in the subscript refers to "Metropolis-Hastings"). The posterior distribution over the belief
div.formula: p * post (x) := p * prior (x) • p * lik (x t ) • (1 − h) + (1/300) • p * lik (x t ) • h (24)
div.p: is a weighted combination of the case that no change point occurs (
div.formula: p * prior (x) • p * lik (x)) and that a change point occurs ((1/300) • p * lik (x)).
div.p: In the no-change-point case, we obtain the posterior by multiplying the prior by the likelihood. In the change-point case, we assume a flat prior (1/300) denoting that all outcomes ∈ [1, 300] are equally likely.

To adjust the amount of sampling dynamically, we added a stopping criterion inspired by the rule for acceptance of new samples as described above. Before sampling starts, the model initializes the hypothetical belief µ sat in the location where the belief update starts (sat in the subscript indicates "satisficing"; Simon, 1956). Depending on the task condition, this initial belief is equal to the previous belief (standard condition) or determined by an external anchor (anchoring condition). According to the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm described above, the model then generates a chunk of n samples and computes a hypothetical belief µ mh reflecting the sample mean. Subsequently, the relative posterior probability of the new sample mean
div.formula: r sat = p * post (µ mh ) p * post (µ sat ) + p * post (µ mh )(25)
div.p: is computed, based on which the model decides whether or not to keep sampling. The model considers that r sat = 0.5 if both hypothetical beliefs are equal and therefore computes the difference between this point and the relative probability of the new sample mean:
div.formula: δ sat = |0.5 − r sat |.(26)
div.p: With unlimited computational resources, a stopping criterion could be δ sat ≈ 0. However, since our model assumes limited resources and aims to reduce the sampling costs, it also considers a criterion value c and stops sampling when δ sat ≤ c. Note that since δ sat takes into account the absolute difference, the model keeps sampling when the hypothetical belief based on the new chunk of samples µ mh is both considerably better and considerably worse than µ sat .

Finally, if the model stops sampling, it commits to the belief conditional on the last chunk µ sat (Fig. 6a). Note that if the first chunk of samples is rejected, µ sat is equal to the starting point of belief updating. In the absence of an external anchor, this consequently yields perseveration. If the model continues the sampling process, it first sets µ sat = µ mh , generates a new chunk of n samples, and sets µ mh to the new sample mean under consideration of the most recent samples.

At the end of a trial, the model updates estimation uncertainty σ 2 t (eq. 9) under consideration of relative uncertainty τ t (eq. 10) and change-point probability ω t (eq. (8)). In contrast to the reduced Bayesian model, where change-point probability is based on the prediction error, the sampling model approximates change-point probability based on the samples. That is, it first computes ω t for each sample (i.e., the differences between the samples and the prior belief (x − µ t )) and then computes the average across these values.

div.head: Motor model
div.p: We applied the motor model to test if movement costs might provide an alternative explanation for perseveration and anchoring. In addition to the variables of the reduced Bayesian model, the motor model is represented by
, which denotes constant costs for each potential position of the bucket and
• e ∈ R >0 , which denotes the cost exponent.

The motor model computed movement costs directly in relation to the required update magnitude on the screen. Every updating step was associated with some amount of cost. Accordingly, perseveration and anchoring occurred to reduce these types of costs.

We assumed that participants would minimize the combined costs resulting from inaccurate predictions due to under-adjustments of their bucket ("error costs") and motor costs. Error costs due to under-adjustments of the bucket were defined in terms of the distance between the potential bucket location x and the optimal belief µ t :
div.formula: l t = (v l • x − µ t ) e l .(27)
div.p: Thus, moving the bucket to the optimal belief µ t according to the reduced Bayesian model would minimize error costs. In contrast, placing the bucket far away from the optimal belief would be associated with higher error costs.
Next, we defined motor costs in relation to the starting point of the updating process z t :
div.formula: m t = (v m • x − z t ) em(28)
div.p: and assumed that participants would report the belief b t+1 that minimizes the summed costs
div.formula: b t+1 = argmin(l t + m t ).(29)

div.head: Software and data repository
div.p: Pseudonymized experimental data in brain imaging data structure (BIDS) format (Gorgolewski et al., 2016) and the Python analysis code are available at https://github.com/rasmusbruckner/ adaptivelearning_analysis. The task was programmed in Matlab (The Mathworks Inc., USA) using the Psychtoolbox (Brainard, 1997;Pelli, 1997;Kleiner, Brainard, & Pelli, 2007), MGL (http://gru.stanford.edu/ doku.php?id=mgl:overview), and SnowDots (http://code.google.com/p/snow-dots) extensions. Data analysis and computational modeling were performed in Python 3.8 (Python Software Foundation; https://www.python.org/). We used the NumPy (Harris et al., 2020), SciPy (Virtanen et al., 2020), pandas (McKinney, 2010), statsmodels (Seabold & Perktold, 2010), matplotlib (Hunter, 2007), seaborn (Waskom, 2021), PIL (https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/index. html), and tqdm (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.1239851) libraries. Protected exceedance probabilities were computed in SPM12 (Penny, Friston, Ashburner, Kiebel, & Nichols, 2011) using Matlab.

div.head: Task design and model predictions
div.p: To examine age differences in adaptive learning across the lifespan, we analyzed behavioral data of 33 children (8 to 10 years, median age 9.0 years), 29 adolescents (13 to 17 years, median age 15.0 years), 32 younger adults (20 to 28 years, median age 24.0 years), and 35 older adults (62 to 80 years, median age 71.0 years). The participants' processing speed and verbal knowledge were assessed using the Identical Picture and Spot-a-Word test, and both of these measures were comparable to scores in previous work (see SM Identical Picture and Spot-a-Word tests; ). In the experimental task, participants were instructed to maximize the collection of coins in bags dropped off by an invisible helicopter ( Fig. 2a; . Participants tried to catch the dropped bags by placing a virtual bucket at the next expected bag location. However, because clouds covered the sky, participants could not directly observe the helicopter and thus had to learn its location based on the history of observed bags. The windy environment distorted the dropped bags' position and induced variability in the outcomes. Hence, participants could utilize the previous bags to estimate the hidden location of the helicopter, but estimates were uncertain. Technically, we generated these outcomes using a Gaussian distribution, where the mean was equal to the position of the hidden helicopter, and the standard deviation led to variability across outcomes. The helicopter occasionally changed its position at "change points", after which previously learned predictions became inaccurate, and . Experimental task and reduced Bayesian model. a In the experimental task, participants tried to catch bags containing gold or stones that were dropped by a hidden helicopter. Participants caught the bags by placing a bucket at the expected position of the bag on the screen (Prediction). The helicopter then dropped the bag (Outcome), a red line marked the prediction error (Prediction error), and participants could adjust their prediction of the bag location for the next trial (Update). This task schematic shows the transition from the first to the second trial. b The helicopter position (dashed line, first panel) was stable on most trials and only changed occasionally (change point). Outcomes (black dots, first panel) were noisy because they were randomly displaced with respect to the helicopter position. The black line in the first panel shows the prediction of the reduced Bayesian model that inferred the position of the hidden helicopter based on the position of the dropped bags. The model computed prediction errors (second panel) to update its predictions. The learning rate (LR; third panel) controls the influence of prediction errors on the model's belief update. In the reduced Bayesian model, the magnitude of the learning rate depends on change-point probability (CPP) and relative uncertainty (RU).

the best strategy was to re-learn the hidden helicopter location. Notably, because the helicopter was not directly observable, the change points were difficult to distinguish from the variability due to the wind in the environment. Participants received rewards for catching gold coins that emerged from dropped bags on a random subset of trials. The task was designed to minimize the contribution of differences in working memory to age-related differences in adaptive learning behavior. In particular, we showed participants their trial-by-trial prediction errors with a red line and, therefore, participants were not required to remember their previous prediction or the most recent outcome (see Experimental task). We confirmed that the different age groups had similar levels of performance on "catch trials" in which we showed the helicopter explicitly, suggesting a comparable understanding of the task instructions and necessary visual and motor capabilities (see SM Catch-trial control analysis). Normative trends in learning behavior can be formally captured by a near-optimal reduced Bayesian model that adjusts the rate of learning on each trial (Fig. 2b;McGuire et al., 2014;Nassar et al., 2012;Vaghi et al., 2017). The model learns according to principles of an error-correcting delta rule as common in reinforcement learning (Daw, 2014;Dayan & Daw, 2008 trial-wise position based on prediction errors that result from a comparison between actual and predicted outcomes. To revise beliefs appropriately, the model scales prediction errors according to a learning rate to produce an update in the expected helicopter location. The Bayesian model dynamically adjusts the learning rate from trial to trial, reflecting attributions of prediction errors to variability across outcomes versus change points in the helicopter location. After smaller prediction errors that are more likely due to outcome variability, the model subtly regulates the learning rate according to its relative uncertainty about the hidden helicopter location. In contrast, prediction errors that are more likely due to a change point, as indicated by change-point probability, lead to higher learning rates and more substantial belief updates (see Reduced Bayesian model).

div.head: Age-related learning differences are driven by perseveration
div.p: Performance in the task differed between age groups. To examine task performance, we compared the estimation errors across age groups, which reflect the absolute difference between the true but unknown location of the helicopter and the participants' prediction of the next outcome ( Fig. 3a). Lower values indicate a more accurate estimate of the helicopter location (see Data preprocessing). According to a Kruskal-Wallis one-way analysis of variance on ranks (hereafter referred to as ANOVA), estimation errors were significantly different between the age groups (H = 32.069, p < 0.001). Post-hoc two-sided Mann-Whitney U tests indicated that children (median = 12.711, IQR 11.594 to 14.445) showed significantly higher estimation errors compared to adolescents (median = 10.791, IQR 9.794 to 12.304; u = 724.0, p = 0.001, R 2 = 0.193) and younger adults (median = 10.311, IQR 9.176 to 12.075; u = 862.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.295).

Older adults (median = 12.433, IQR 11.658 to 13.704) had significantly higher estimation errors compared with adolescents (u = 258.0, p = 0.001, R 2 = 0.176) and younger adults (u = 205.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.296). The test did not yield significant differences between children and older adults (u = 625.0, p = 0.564, R 2 = 0.005) and between adolescents and younger adults (u = 523.0, p = 0.398, R 2 = 0.012). An analysis of the average learning rates showed that, on average, children and older adults updated their predictions to a lesser degree compared to the other two age groups ( Fig. 3b and Average learning-rate analysis). The average learning rate provides a model-agnostic measure of the extent to which participants update their prediction in response to the prediction error across all trials, where lower learning rates would reflect that prediction errors are, on average, considered to a lesser extent. An ANOVA indicated that learning rates were significantly different between the age groups (H = 32.001, p < 0.001). Post-hoc tests showed significantly lower average learning rates in children (median = 0.734, IQR 0.626 to 0.798) compared with adolescents (median = 0.845, IQR 0.8 to 0.887; u = 137.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.373) and younger adults (median = 0.838, IQR 0.793 to 0.887; u = 188.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.305). Post-hoc tests also yielded significantly lower learning rates in older adults (median = 0.788, IQR 0.711 to 0.842) compared to adolescents (u = 738.0, p = 0.002, R 2 = 0.15) and young adults (u = 779.0, p = 0.006, R 2 = 0.112). The test did not yield significant differences between children and older adults (u = 431.0, p = 0.073, R 2 = 0.047) and between adolescents and younger adults (u = 503.0, p = 0.578, R 2 = 0.005). Thus, children and older adults use lower learning rates than adolescents and younger adults, suggesting that, on average, children and older adults consider prediction errors weaker for belief updating. While the previous analysis indicates that children and older adults use lower learning rates on average, it leaves open why these differences originate. Therefore, to better understand the computational underpinnings of age-related learning differences, we next analyzed the trial-bytrial dynamics of learning-rate adjustments in the different age groups using the reduced Bayesian model. To do so, we equipped the model with several free parameters derived from previous work that we estimated using a maximum-likelihood approach (see Evaluation and estimation). These parameters could be successfully recovered in our parameter-recovery analysis (see SM Parameter-recovery analysis). In line with our previous study comparing younger and older adults in the helicopter task, we found evidence for a reduced consideration of relative uncertainty in older compared to younger adults. However, these differences did not explain our observed performance differences between the age groups, nor did we observe any meaningful lifespan differences in subjective assumption about the frequency of change points (hazard rate). Thus, while the Bayesian model could explain many aspects of behavior, it could not account for our observed lifespan differences in performance (see SM Supplementary modeling results first experiment).

In addition to considering differences in such costly computations involved in selecting a learning rate, we also considered the possibility that individuals might employ frugal policies for implementing it. In particular, our motivating sampling framework suggests that participants should often perseverate on their previous prediction (Fig. 1). In line with this prediction, all four age groups showed perseveration in the task, that is, they repeated the same prediction across two or more consecutive trials (Fig. 3c). An ANOVA yielded significantly different estimated perseveration probabilities across the age groups (H = 27.229, p < 0.001). The estimated perseveration probability in children (median = 0.565, IQR 0.428 to 0.748) was significantly higher compared to adolescents (median = 0.238, IQR 0.13 to 0.465; u = 752.5, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.24), younger adults (median = 0.23, IQR 0.113 to 0.43; u = 859.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.289), and older adults (median = 0.495, IQR 0.312 to 0.586; u = 739.5, p = 0.047, R 2 = 0.058). We also found significantly higher perseveration probabilities in older adults than in adolescents (u = 307.0, p = 0.007, R 2 = 0.114) and in older compared to younger adults (u = 320.0, p = 0.003, R 2 = 0.135). The test did not show a significant difference between adolescents and younger adults (u = 478.0, p = 0.845, R 2 = 0.001). These results show that all age groups perseverated on their predictions, but such perseveration was more pronounced in children and older adults compared to adolescents and younger adults.

In our computational approach, we captured age-related differences in perseveration by extending our optimal Bayesian model (see SM Computational modeling), allowing for a better explanation of participant data than the original Bayesian model (see SM Model comparison). A key observation from this modeling is that perseveration did not occur randomly and instead was most common in trials where participants made the smallest prediction errors. Model-based analyses using the extended version of the reduced Bayesian model capturing perseveration revealed that age-related differences in perseveration probability were particularly pronounced for trials where the model predicted small to intermediate updates ( Fig. 3d and SM Supplementary modeling results first experiment for parameter estimates).

Our results raise the question of whether perseveration reflects an adaptive strategy for more efficient learning in children and older adults or whether it should be interpreted in terms of a learning deficit. The sampling perspective sketched above would suggest that perseveration might be employed to strategically trade accuracy for savings in computational cost. In line with this perspective, perseveration primarily occurred for smaller prediction errors, where no updating would have a minimal impact on belief accuracy. However, the results so far would also align with the hypothesis that perseveration reflects a learning deficit that is the primary source of lower performance in children and older adults. Mainly because in a simulation study, we found that model-predicted learning performance across the lifespan is quite similar when perseveration is absent (see SM Model validation). Therefore, to resolve whether perseveration reflects an adaptive strategy or a learning deficit, we conducted a second experiment that included an anchoring manipulation suppressing perseveration.

div.head: Reducing perseveration leads to the anchoring bias
div.p: To better understand the computational mechanisms underlying lifespan differences in belief updating, we conducted a second experiment examining the effect of external anchors on task performance. Such anchors were implemented by randomly perturbing the bucket position at the beginning of each trial in a manner that would make it more challenging to repeat the previous trial's prediction exactly. As described above, from the perspective of a resource-rational sampling model, the anchoring manipulation would be expected to lead to impaired performance due to anchoring biases, which would be even more pronounced in children and older adults. In particular, drawing fewer samples due to lower cognitive resources would not completely overwrite the effect of external anchors, and it might be more efficient to trade accuracy for fewer invested cognitive resources. In contrast, the perseverative reduced Bayesian model would predict that the anchoring manipulation should, if anything, improve task performance, particularly in children and older adults who are more prone to perseverative responses.

To test these ideas, we conducted a follow-up experiment with an effective participant sample of 31 children (7 to 11 years, median age 9.0 years), 25 younger adults (20 to 28 years, median age 24.0 years), and 34 older adults (61 to 76 years, median age 67.0 years). Out of efficiency considerations, we did not test adolescents as they showed similar levels of perseveration as younger adults in the first experiment. The psychometric profile of the participants was similar to the first experiment (see SM Identical Picture and Spot-a-Word tests). We used a modified version of the helicopter task that included two task conditions intended to reduce the frequency of perseverative responses. In the anchoring condition, we randomly perturbed the bucket's initial location at the onset of each trial (Fig. 4a). The consequence of the bucket randomization was that participants could not repeat the previous trial's prediction using a single key press, as this would now require them to adjust their bucket back to its previous position. We presented this anchoring condition in two out of four task blocks. The other two blocks were similar to the In the anchoring condition, we randomly relocated the location of the bucket that participants used to catch bags according to a normal distribution centered on the previous bucket location (anchor). In the standard condition, the bucket stayed at the participants' previous predictions as in the first experiment. This task schematic shows the transition from the first to the second trial. b The upper plot shows the outcomes in the task (black dots), an example of the predicted outcomes according to a simulation using the reduced Bayesian model (black line) and the anchor location (blue dots). To capture the anchoring bias, we added a parameter to the model, such that the predictions of the reduced Bayesian model were biased towards the anchor. The lower panel shows the shift in the initial bucket location (the difference between the previous and current bucket location).

standard helicopter task as in the first experiment. Second, we included a reward-magnitude manipulation in which we subdivided trials into high-and low-reward trials, thereby incentivizing participants to reduce perseverative behaviors on the high-reward trials. Reward-magnitude manipulations did not significantly affect the perseverative response frequency (see SM Supplementary results follow-up experiment), and thus, we focus our analyses on the anchoring condition. As in the first experiment, the task featured catch trials, on which the helicopter was visible. All age groups performed similarly, indicating that they understood the task instructions and had similar visual and motor capabilities (see SM Catch-trial control analysis).

We found that randomizing the start location of the bucket strongly reduced perseveration in all age groups (Fig. 5a). An ANOVA indicated that in the anchoring condition, the absolute perseveration frequency was not significantly different between the groups (H = 0.381, p = 0.827). This result suggests that in the new anchoring condition, all age groups perseverated at a similar level. In line with this finding, an ANOVA comparing the perseveration difference between the standard helicopter and anchoring conditions showed that the condition difference was significantly differed across age groups (H = 20.697, p < 0.001). Post-hoc tests showed a significantly stronger reduction in children compared to younger adults (u = 186.0, p = 0.001, R 2 = 0.196). Compared to older adults, younger adults showed significantly lower perseveration differences between the conditions (u = 724.5, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.357). The test did not In the standard condition, perseveration was comparable to the results in the first experiment. b Despite perseveration being absent, in the anchoring condition, children and older adults showed significantly lower performance (larger estimation errors) compared to the standard condition. We did not find a significant performance difference between the two conditions in younger adults. In line with this, the performance difference between the standard and anchoring condition was significantly larger in children and older adults than in younger adults. c Children and older adults showed a stronger anchoring bias than younger adults. d The estimated anchoring bias and perseveration probability were systematically related to each other in that a higher perseveration probability statistically predicted a stronger anchoring bias, suggesting that both biases emerge from a common underlying cause.

yield a significant difference between children and older adults (u = 549.5, p = 0.773; R 2 = 0.001). We additionally refer to the supplemental material for within-subject comparison of the conditions (SM Supplementary results follow-up experiment). Finally, this reduction in perseveration was not simply due to a substitution effect. Participants almost never left their bucket in exactly the externally determined location, but they actively updated their reported beliefs (SM Supplementary results follow-up experiment "motor" perseveration results). Thus, our task manipulation successfully normalized the primary factor contributing to age-related performance differences in our previous experiment. If perseveration were truly the primary computational deficit driving age-related performance differences as suggested by the perseverative reduced Bayesian model, then suppressing it should rescue learning behavior in children in older adults (see SM Model validation). However, alternatively, if perseveration reflects a more liberal sampling policy in our sampling framework, then the performance of children and older adults would be even more impaired due to the emergence of the anchoring bias when the initial bucket position is randomized (Fig. 1). This prediction follows because perseveration mostly occurs on smaller prediction errors, and external anchors can be far away from previous predictions, which could only be compensated by drawing more samples. In line with the sampling perspective, the anchoring manipulation did not rescue performance in our target age groups but instead led to additional impairments (Fig. 5b). An ANOVA on the within-participant differences in estimation errors between the two task conditions showed a significant difference between the age groups (H = 15.705, p < 0.001). Post-hoc tests revealed significantly higher estimation-error differences between the anchoring and standard conditions in children compared to younger adults (u = 576.0, p = 0.002, R 2 = 0.171) and younger adults compared to older adults (u = 186.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.227) but not between children and older adults (u = 444.0, p = 0.279, R 2 = 0.018). That is, in line with the prediction of the sampling framework, the anchoring manipulation led to additional performance impairments in children and older adults.

Consistent with our sampling account, age-related performance differences in the anchoring condition were driven by anchoring biases. The anchoring bias was significantly different between the age groups ( Fig. 5c; H = 27.356, p < 0.001). Post-hoc tests showed a significantly stronger bias in children (median = 0.14, IQR 0.098 to 0.258) compared to younger adults (median = 0.057, IQR 0.017 to 0.106; u = 615.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.25), and in older adults (median = 0.268, IQR 0.136 to 0.392) compared with younger adults (u = 116.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.38). In children, the anchoring bias was significantly lower compared to older adults (u = 345.0, p = 0.017, R 2 = 0.087). We confirmed that learning in these age groups was more substantially affected by the anchoring bias in a model-based analysis ( Fig. S10i and SM Supplementary modeling results follow-up experiment). Here, the anchoring bias was governed by an additional free parameter, where higher parameter values indicate a stronger bias that showed similar agerelated differences in the effect of the anchor on learning. Finally, in a control analysis, we found no convincing evidence that performance differences across groups were explained by differences in average learning rates (SM Average learning rate follow-up experiment).

In summary, the results suggest a relationship between perseverative responses characterizing the behavior of children and older adults in our first experiment and anchoring biases on learning that characterize their behavior in the second experiment. To test whether these two effects might emerge from a common underlying cause, we examined the relationship between them (see Robust regression). As would be expected if the two effects emerged from a common cause, participants who tended to perseverate more often in the standard condition were also more strongly biased by the initial prediction location in the anchoring condition (Fig. 5d). A robust regression indicated a strong effect size (R 2 = 0.281; intercept β 0 = -0.004, z = -0.111, p = 0.911; regression slope β 1 = 0.407, z = 5.294, p < 0.001). Thus, in line with our sampling perspective, perseveration in children and older adults did not reflect a strong adherence to prior beliefs per se but rather a sensitivity to the starting value of the belief update, be it internally or externally generated (see also SM Robust regression with age group for an analysis that additionally models group differences in this relationship).

div.head: Age-related learning differences are driven by resource-rational sampling
div.p: The results of the two experiments are in line with the key predictions of our motivating sampling framework. As such, they suggest that age-related learning biases emerge from efficient belief-updating computations that reduce the amount of cognitive resources invested in learning. However, previous learning models, including the perseverative reduced Bayesian model, cannot capture this idea, particularly the relationship between perseveration and anchoring. Therefore, we propose a new sampling model that formalizes and qualitatively supports this perspective.

The sampling model embeds the computations of the reduced Bayesian model in a resourcerational or computationally rational framework (Lieder & Griffiths, 2020;Gershman, Horvitz, & Tenenbaum, 2015). The key assumption is that belief updating resembles sampling algorithms from statistics and machine learning (Lieder et al., 2018;Vul et al., 2014), combined with a criterion value determining when the updating process stops and the belief is reported (Fig. 1). Accordingly, the brain sequentially adjusts its belief within a trial by generating samples stochastically, which approximates optimal inference if sufficient samples are drawn ( Fig. 6b and SM Sampling model for a systematic comparison to the reduced Bayesian model, a trialby-trial illustration, and a model-validation analysis). However, because the brain has limited computational resources, it terminates the sampling process before completely approximating the optimal belief to ensure that the computational costs of sampling do not exceed the benefits.

We first briefly explain how sampling can approximate optimal learning in our task (for more details, see Sampling model). Then, we explain how our sampling model dynamically adjusts how much to sample from trial to trial. One challenge in Bayesian inference is to compute the posterior distribution analytically, and Markov Chain Monte-Carlo (MCMC) sampling allows The model first generates a chunk of samples and compares the sample mean to the initial belief (the starting point of the sampling process) in terms of their accuracy. In particular, this comparison is based on a criterion value: when the relative posterior probability of the initial belief compared to the sample mean is below the stopping criterion, the model rejects the new samples in favor of the prior, as the new samples did not sufficiently improve the belief. If the starting location of belief updating is the prior belief, this yields perseveration. If the relative posterior probability of the two potential beliefs is above the criterion value, the model keeps sampling. This cycle would then be repeated until the relative posterior probability of sample chunk n and n − 1 is below the criterion, and the model updates the belief. b Illustration of the sampling model with a large number of samples that closely approximate the optimal belief distribution. c Example of a trial on which the model perseverates. Perseveration takes place when (i) sampling starts from the prior belief, (ii) a limited amount of samples is drawn, and (iii) the sample mean is not sufficiently better than the prior. d Example of the anchoring bias. The new belief is biased when (i) sampling starts from an external anchor and (ii) a limited number of samples is accepted that cannot override the effect of the external anchor. Model simulations reproduce the major empirical findings. e Perseveration probability across the age groups, showing that perseveration is more frequent in the standard condition (darker colors, boxplots for simulated CH, YA, OA on the left) than in the anchoring condition (lighter colors, boxplots on the right). Median perseveration probabilities are plotted with blue diamonds to compare simulations to the empirical data. f Estimation errors were greater in the anchoring condition, and g the magnitude of the simulated anchoring biases was comparable to our empirical data. In these simulations, we assumed that the stopping criterion values of children and older adults are more liberal compared to younger adults, which could correspond to the willingness to exert cognitive effort, thereby leading to faster rejection of new samples. Moreover, we assumed that the sample-chunk size is smaller in children and older adults compared to younger adults, which could correspond to an individual's amount of cognitive resources.

us to approximate the posterior based on sampling. For example, to compute the belief about the helicopter location, MCMC algorithms would sequentially draw random samples from the distribution of possible helicopter locations, which only requires that we can compute the unnormalized probability density of each drawn sample with respect to the "target" distribution about possible helicopter locations. When drawing a large number of samples, we could approx-imate the mean (most likely helicopter location) and variance (uncertainty about the location) without using analytical equations (Fig. 6b).

Assuming the brain relies on sampling to approximate Bayesian inference, it needs a mechanism to decide when to stop sampling. Our model stops sampling after drawing a new set of samples that do not sufficiently improve the belief (Fig. 6a). Specifically, the model iteratively (i) draws a set of samples and (ii) evaluates whether more samples are necessary.
