Samples are drawn from a proposal distribution that is normal and centered on the previous sample and accepted according to their un-normalized posterior probability (see eqs. 25and 26), thereby allowing samples to evolve over time to match the true posterior probability distribution over helicopter locations. Stopping is achieved by comparing the un-normalized posterior probability of the mean of the sample distribution with and without the new chunk of samples; when new samples do not sufficiently increase the posterior probability, the model discards them, stops sampling, and reports the mean of the sample chain as its estimate of the helicopter location.

These sampling dynamics are controlled by two parameters. The chunk-size parameter determines the number of samples per chunk and might reflect the amount of invested cognitive resources per unit of time. The stopping criterion governs the evaluation process after generating each chunk of samples. When the criterion parameter is more conservative (≈ 0), the model only stops sampling when more samples clearly do not improve belief accuracy anymore and generally tends to generate more sampling chunks. In contrast, when the criterion parameter is more liberal (> 0), the model would also stop sampling when the probability of the un-normalized posterior probability of the mean of the sample distribution with and without the new chunk is similar but not necessarily equal. Therefore, the criterion parameter can be interpreted as the willingness to invest cognitive resources.

We next illustrate how sampling can yield perseveration and anchoring. Perseveration occurs when the belief update starts from the prior belief and the first chunk of samples gets rejected (Fig. 6c). In line with our experimental data, the model predicts that perseveration primarily takes place after smaller prediction errors, where the prior belief and the potentially updated belief based on new samples would be quite similar (compare Fig. 3d and Fig. S18a). In contrast, anchoring takes place when belief updating starts from an externally determined value and the criterion is reached before the new samples have completely compensated for the effect of the anchor (Fig. 6d). In particular, when the starting point of belief updating is far away from the optimal (but unknown) belief, and the model only considers a small number of samples. Consequently, the model predicts a more substantial anchoring bias when an externally generated anchor is far from the optimal belief (Fig. S18b).

We performed a simulation study in which the simulated perseveration and anchoring effects resembled our empirical results. We assumed that due to smaller chunk sizes and more liberal criterion values, children and older adults (average chunk size ≈ 4 and 3.5, respectively; average criterion ≈ 0.012 and 0.017; see Sampling model) draw a lower number of samples compared to younger adults (average chunk size ≈ 20, average criterion ≈ 0.01). The simulated participants showed a pattern of perseveration comparable to the experimental data, with heightened perseveration in children and older adults (Fig. 6e). Similarly, compared to younger adults, simulated children and older adults showed larger estimation errors in the anchoring task condition (Fig. 6g). Moreover, the anchoring bias was stronger in children and older adults when compared to younger adults (Fig. 6h). Lastly, the model also captured the relationship between perseveration and anchoring within each age group (Fig. S15b). Thus, our simulations could reproduce the pattern of age-related differences by assuming that belief updating occurs through an iterative sampling process and that children and older adults have more limited cognitive resources and are less willing to deploy them in the service of belief updating.

div.head: Resource-only and motor models do not capture learning biases
div.p: Finally, we found that neither a resource-only model nor a motor model that we included as alternative control models successfully explained the observed age-related learning differences. The first control model was a resource-only model that lacked the dynamic stopping criterion of our resource-rational model. The second control model was a motor-control model, which assumed that motor costs lead to the observed biases.

The resource-only model resembled the sampling model but did not use the dynamic stopping criterion. Instead, the resource-only model sampled a fixed number of samples that differed between the age groups. As such, instead of adjusting the amount of resources dynamically, the model invested a fixed amount on each trial, and the simulated age groups only differed with respect to their cognitive resources. However, this model did not convincingly explain the observed age-related biases (see SM Resource-only model). Specifically, when the fixed number of samples successfully captured perseveration, it strongly overestimated estimation errors and anchoring biases (children and older adults, 2 samples; younger adults, 10 samples). In contrast, when the simulations reproduced the estimation errors and anchoring, the model strongly underestimated perseveration (20 vs. 50 samples).

Moreover, the motor-control model added a parameterized motor penalty to the reduced Bayesian model as commonly used in motor-control frameworks (see Motor model for more details). The critical parameter of this model determined the relative cost associated with small versus large movements. As such, the model assumed that participants would navigate a trade-off between maximizing prediction accuracy (favoring larger updates) and minimizing motor costs (favoring smaller updates). However, the motor model failed to explain our findings comprehensively (see SM Motor model). Specifically, when we assumed high movement costs that accurately described the perseveration results, it strongly overestimated the anchoring bias. Similarly, when we attempted to realistically capture the anchoring bias by setting the motor-cost parameters to lower values, we underestimated perseveration in the standard task condition.

In summary, the new sampling model qualitatively captures the age-related differences in perseveration and anchoring and shows that the findings across the two experiments could be produced by a resource-rational sampling mechanism that adjusts the computational expenditure according to the available cognitive resources.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Learning is essential for adaptive behavior. However, children and older adults often show reduced performance than younger adults across a wide array of tasks. In canonical decisionmaking and cognitive control tasks, these impairments are often due to perseverative behavior. However, when additional task-related cues are presented, children and older adults are more strongly influenced (biased) by environmental information. Currently, we lack a satisfactory computational explanation for when and why individuals exhibit these biases at different stages of their lifespan. Here, we developed a computational model that explains the emergence of perseveration and anchoring in terms of a trade-off between belief accuracy and computational cost during learning. We showed that, in this model, computational costs could be reduced by drawing only limited samples from the optimal Bayesian belief distribution for reasonably small reductions in accuracy. Crucially, when the model is parameterized in a computationally frugal manner, it can explain both perseveration and anchoring. Across studies, we show that belief updating behavior was primarily characterized by performance deficits due to persevera-tion (when updating from a previous belief) and anchoring (when updating from an externally determined location), in line with the predictions of our model. Importantly, perseveration was correlated with anchoring, suggesting that both biases share a common cause related to the costs of mental computation. Therefore, we suggest that learning impairments in children and older adults may reflect biases that reduce computational costs while ensuring satisfactory cognitive task performance.

Sampling has been suggested as a cognitively plausible mechanism for approximate inference. One argument for this perspective is that optimal Bayesian inference is costly and often intractable in real-life scenarios (Vul et al., 2014;Gershman & Beck, 2017;Sanborn & Chater, 2016). Moreover, sampling is an approach to quantifying the required cognitive resources for computations in terms of the number of samples (Lieder et al., 2018;Lieder & Griffiths, 2020;Dasgupta et al., 2017). Accordingly, each sample that is drawn represents a limited resource, and drawing more samples leads to more accurate beliefs but also takes more time and effort. Therefore, people would be expected to rely on fewer samples, compared to what would be required to closely approximate Bayesian inference, which has been shown to give rise to behavioral biases such as anchoring and generally higher response variability than predicted by exact Bayesian inference models (Dasgupta et al., 2017;Vul et al., 2014;Lieder et al., 2018). Our results are in line with these studies but extend them to a more complex task with dynamic changes to reveal that perseverative and anchoring biases can both emerge from a sampling process depending on how beliefs are probed and that limited sampling provides a parsimonious account of age differences in adaptive learning behavior.

Importantly, our results support the hypothesis that learning differences across the lifespan could be linked to the amount of cognitive resources . In particular, our model simulations suggest that children and older adults are best described as learners who draw fewer samples, yielding stronger perseveration ( Fig. 6e) and anchoring biases (Fig. 6g) when compared to their young adult counterparts. In what follows, we provide a unifying framework proposing that the reliance on sampling might be a common cause underlying perseverative behavior and greater anchoring biases in children and older adults across different task domains.

Perseverative behavior is common in children and older adults, and it often leads to substantial performance deficits in these age groups compared to younger adults. It has been observed in various experimental tasks where performance relies on the flexible updating of task representations such as reversal learning (Crone, Jennings, & Van der Molen, 2004;Head et al., 2009;Ridderinkhof et al., 2002;Rutledge et al., 2009) or task switching Carroll et al., 2016;Cepeda & Munakata, 2007;Crone, Ridderinkhof, et al., 2004;Munakata et al., 2012). Children's reduced performance in these tasks is often interpreted in terms of executive control deficits, particularly working memory limitations. Our modeling approach offers a partially alternative mechanistic interpretation of these limitations in adaptive behavior. We suggest that due to lower cognitive resources and willingness to expend them, children and older adults might rely on fewer samples when making judgments about new stimuli. As a consequence of reduced sampling, they more frequently perseverate on previous responses in reversal-learning or task-switching paradigms (as they do in the current task). Importantly, in our experiments, perseveration was particularly frequent on trials with smaller prediction errors, where our sampling model predicts the rejection of new samples. This finding aligns with a previous developmental study that used a sampling model in a hypothesis-testing task . The results indicated that children tended to stick to their choices when confirmed. In contrast, they were more likely to sample alternative hypotheses when choices were disconfirmed, similar to our model, where larger prediction errors are associated with more sampling and less perseveration.

Our finding of increased anchoring biases on learning in older adults is consistent with theoretical ideas that propose a shift from internal to environmental control with age (Craik & Bialystok, 2006;Lindenberger & Mayr, 2014). Lindenberger and Mayr (2014) suggest that across a range of psychological domains and experimental tasks, for example, task switching, inhibitory working memory, or attentional control, less differentiated internal representations in older adults are associated with an increased reliance on environmental information. Our model formalizes this idea by assuming that external cues act as anchors determining the starting point from which beliefs are updated. In effect, when the number of considered samples does not offset the anchor, beliefs are biased toward the externally provided information. This environmental control bias should be more pronounced in individuals with lower cognitive resources (such as older adults) because the sampling process would stop after fewer samples. So far, the environmental control framework has been primarily applied to the upper end of the lifespan. However, several findings from the developmental literature can be interpreted along the lines of this theory (Alarcón & Bonardi, 2020). For example, younger children tend to rely more on what has been referred to as reactive control (Chatham et al., 2009;Gonthier et al., 2019;Troller-Renfree et al., 2020). That is, they retrieve task-relevant information when needed (in response to an external cue) instead of maintaining the relevant information proactively (Munakata et al., 2012). From a sampling perspective, reactive control could emerge from the reliance on only a few samples, while proactive control could be the consequence of a longer sampling process, which requires more cognitive resources.

The results of the current study extend our previous work, which suggested that age differences in learning were due to an underestimation of uncertainty in older adults . In our prior publication, we used the same task as in the first experiment of the current study. The analyses suggested that older adults underestimated uncertainty more strongly than younger adults, which led to reduced learning rates for smaller prediction errors. While we replicate this effect here, we also found evidence indicating that a portion of what had initially appeared as an underestimation of uncertainty in can be attributed to perseveration (see SM Control model). Both effects largely concern small to medium prediction errors and lead to under-adjustments in response to such errors. However, the effects differ in so far as perseveration corresponds to a learning rate of exactly zero, while uncertainty underestimation leads to reduced learning rates, usually still larger than zero. Therefore, the two effects go in the same direction, and the current study suggests that perseveration is the major source of reduced learning rates in children and older adults compared to their young adult counterparts.

Notably, we have not found any systematic differences in performance between adolescents and younger adults. A popular perspective holds that adolescents are particularly susceptible to rewards, leading to increased risk-taking and more behavioral flexibility compared to younger adults (Van Duijvenvoorde, Peters, Braams, & Crone, 2016;Somerville & Casey, 2010). From this point of view, one might have expected reward-related effects (e.g., related to rewarding gold bags vs. neutral bags containing stones) in adolescents compared to adults in our study. However, more recent perspectives emphasize that the environment (or the task in lab studies), and not only the adolescent brain, sculpts risk preferences (Ciranka & van den Bos, 2021). For example, in the real world, adolescents have more opportunities to take risks, and these opportunities are novel and, therefore, more uncertain for adolescents than for adults. From this perspective, our findings might be explained by the fact that our task environment did not provide sufficient room for the emergence of reward-driven biases. A related reason for the absence of these effects could be that in our task (in the first experiment that included adolescents), rewards could not be predicted, and the optimal learning strategy is to ignore the rewards. The idea that reward-related biases in adolescents might be context-and task-dependent is also consistent with results from a recent lifespan developmental study on effort-reward trade-offs in cognitive control (Devine et al., 2021). Consistent with the current results, the findings of this study indicate that the sensitivity to these trade-offs depends on the cognitive resources of the individuals, which are more similar in adolescents and younger adults than they are in children and older adults compared to younger adults.

Moreover, one might have expected that adolescents would overestimate environmental changes. A recent study by Jepma, Schaaf, Visser, and Huizenga (2020) used a similar task as we applied in our study, and the authors suggested that adolescents rely on higher learning rates due to an overestimation of environmental changes compared to younger adults. We did not find such an effect in the current experiment. However, it is important to note that there is one major difference between the two studies: In contrast to our study, the task by Jepma et al. (2020) did not involve any change points (but modeled individual assumptions about changes). Therefore, our changing environment potentially better matched the adolescents' assumptions about changes. In order to shed more light on these differences, future studies should systematically compare learning in adolescents in stable and changing environments.

Next, we discuss our null result of the incentive manipulation that we used to test whether reward magnitudes modulate perseveration. In the follow-up experiment, we applied high-and low-reward conditions but did not find significant differences in perseveration between these conditions. In contrast to our expectations, performance was even slightly better on low-reward trials (see SM Results follow-up experiment). One potential explanation for this result is that higher expected rewards biased learning and thereby diminished performance to some extent. Previous fMRI work with the same task has found a reward-related effect of prior rewards (previous trial) on learning rates and brain activity in the ventral striatum (McGuire et al., 2014). However, in the current study, we did not find systematic evidence that average learning rates differed between the high-and low-reward conditions, suggesting that the observed performance differences might be related to how dynamically subjects adjust learning. Therefore, the effects of the incentive manipulation could be interpreted as evidence against a rational use of cognitive resources (since higher reward prospects should motivate subjects to invest more resources and reduce perseveration). However, it is also possible that the manipulation was not strong enough to systematically affect perseveration rates. We do not interpret the absence of evidence of the effect as evidence for the absence of an effect of rewards on perseveration and, more generally, the motivation to invest more cognitive effort. An alternative approach to our trial-by-trial reward manipulation could be to manipulate rewards block-wise, in line with the typical approach in cognitive control studies providing convincing evidence for effects of rewards on the motivation to exert mental effort (Shenhav, Prater Fahey, & Grahek, 2021).

The sampling perspective on learning might remind readers of common sequential sampling models in decision-making, such as the drift-diffusion model (DDM; Forstmann, Ratcliff, & Wagenmakers, 2016;Ratcliff & Rouder, 1998). Indeed, both perspectives share the idea that evidence is sampled sequentially until a criterion is reached. As such, the two parameters of the sampling model (stopping criterion and chunk-size parameter) could be interpreted along the lines of the DDM. The criterion parameter of the sampling model is related to the decision boundaries in the DDM. The chunk-size parameter that influences the amount of sampling has some conceptual similarity to the drift rate of the DDM that determines the speed of evidence accumulation. However, there are also significant differences between the models. Our sampling model is a learning model that relies on active, internal sampling to approximate Bayesian updates. This property allows the model to update internal beliefs across trials based on feedback to improve future decision-making. In contrast, the canonical DDM samples external evidence, often by passively observing a stimulus, until reaching a threshold level of certainty necessary to commit to a categorical choice. That is, in contrast to our sampling model, the DDM is not designed to capture learning.

Previous work on aging and decision-making that used the DDM provides evidence that older adults adopt a higher decision boundary (Dully, McGovern, & O'Connell, 2018;Ratcliff, Thapar, Gomez, & McKoon, 2004;Theisen, Lerche, von Krause, & Voss, 2021). This finding might seem at odds with our suggestion that older adults draw fewer samples than younger adults. One potential explanation for these seemingly opposing findings is the difference between active sampling in the service of learning in our task and passive sampling in the case of categorical decisions that have previously been modeled using the DDM. Older adults might be more conservative in their action selection when sampling happens passively and is less cognitively effortful, like in categorical choice tasks. In contrast, older adults might be more liberal when updating beliefs based on active sampling, as in the present study, which might require more cognitive resources.

Our theory is also related to the study of heuristics, which can be defined as strategies that ignore part of the information to choose more quickly and frugally than more complex methods (Gigerenzer & Gaissmaier, 2011). Heuristics are sometimes treated as fundamentally different strategies that an individual can select given the current choice problem (Mata, Josef, & P., 2015;Van den Bos, Bruckner, Nassar, Mata, & Eppinger, 2018). For example, under time pressure, humans often resort to a simple lexicographic strategy that selects the best alternative on the most important attribute, such as the best possible outcome independent of its probability in a discrete choice task (Rieskamp & Hoffrage, 2008). Regarding lifespan development, research on heuristic decision-making has characterized children's developing ability to rely on more efficient strategies in the service of adaptive decision-making and suggested that older adults select strategies according to the environmental structure (Mata, von Helversen, & Rieskamp, 2011;Mata, Schooler, & Rieskamp, 2007). Our approach can be interpreted along these lines, especially concerning the assumption that heuristics can be efficient under bounded resources (Simon, 1955(Simon, , 1956). One notable difference in our approach is that the current sampling model treats the shift between different strategies (e.g., Bayes-optimal learning versus anchoring) in a more continuous way governed by a common underlying sampling mechanism. Research on heuristics often distinguishes strategies on a more qualitative level, but ultimately, both perspectives aim to capture cognitive biases, and a resource-rational approach can help explain why heuristics emerge (Lieder & Griffiths, 2020).

What might be the cognitive correlates of computational resources and age-related sampling differences? Processing speed could be one potential factor correlating with the number of samples drawn on a mental computation. Consistent with our own findings in both experiments, children and older adults score lower on processing-speed tests, which is linked to the development and decline of reasoning abilities Nettelbeck & Burns, 2010;Kail, Lervåg, & Hulme, 2016;Scheiber, Chen, Kaufman, & Weiss, 2017). One interpretation could be that individuals with lower processing speed can draw fewer samples per unit time than faster individuals, as modeled by our chunk-size parameter. Consequently, drawing the same amount of samples as younger adults would require more time for children and older adults. In addition, each sample might be more effortful or costly, so they are less willing to deploy them, an idea that is reflected in the criterion parameter of the sampling model. Indeed, particularly in older adults, there is evidence that cognitive effort is subjectively more costly compared to younger adults (Westbrook, Kester, & Braver, 2013). Children also seem to be sensitive to cognitive effort and regulate their choice behavior accordingly (Chevalier, 2018, however, it is currently unclear if the costs of subjective effort systematically decrease across childhood devel-opment). Therefore, to save effort, it could be resource-rational for children and older adults to rely on fewer samples . Taken together, our findings seem consistent with recent work suggesting that age differences in the engagement in cost-benefit trade-offs reflect an adaptation to internal and external constraints that arise across the lifespan (Devine et al., 2021;Ruel, Devine, & Eppinger, 2021).

Given the consideration outlined above, it may seem obvious to test the relationship between processing speed and sampling based on reaction-time data. We decided not to include these analyses because reaction times and spatial updates are inherently confounded within the current task. In our model, more extensive updates are associated with more sampling, which should increase the reaction time. However, the issue is that such updates also take longer when moving the bucket toward the required location on the screen. In general, it seems challenging to completely eliminate this confound when examining perseveration and anchoring, at least when spatial updates are involved. For example, one strategy could be to use a circular task design where predictions start from the center of a circle, and all locations on the circle are equidistant to the center (Nassar, Bruckner, & Frank, 2019). Yet, this manipulation would no longer allow participants to perseverate or provoke an anchoring bias. Therefore, future work should develop a task version that de-confounds the time necessary to update beliefs from the time necessary to execute the required actions to report it. Even more generally, when considering reaction times, it should be taken into account that different age groups differ in their processing speed. That is, generating a sample will be faster in younger adults than in children and older adults. Consequently, age-related reaction-time differences would partly reflect differences in how long it takes to generate a sample. One potential way to address this confound could be by estimating a free parameter that reflects the average time per sample.

Last but not least, next to replicating our results in a confirmatory study, future studies should directly estimate the subjective cognitive costs and gains in accuracy during sampling and test whether individual differences predict the number of samples. Quantifying this tradeoff could lead to refined hypotheses about when people, given their limitations, should show stronger behavioral biases. We leave the development of a more sophisticated resource-rational model to future work (e.g., Gershman, 2020;Lieder & Griffiths, 2020;Lieder et al., 2018).

To conclude, in this study, we provide a unifying perspective on cognitive resources and learning biases across the human lifespan. Children and older adults frequently perseverate on prior predictions when updating beliefs from previous values. In contrast, when beliefs are updated from externally manipulated values, learning is affected by anchoring biases. We explain this pattern using a model that suggests that belief updating involves a sampling process that stops when a certain level of accuracy is reached. Our results suggest that due to their lower cognitive resources and willingness to expend them, children and older adults terminate the sampling process earlier than younger adults and, therefore, show stronger behavioral biases. The proposed sampling model may offer a parsimonious explanation for a wide array of findings in the developmental and aging literature on learning and executive control and supports a resource-rationality perspective on lifespan development. . Bayesian online learning of the hazard rate in change-point problems. Neural Computation, 22 (9), 2452-2476. doi:10.1162/NECO_ a_00007

div.head: Supplemental Material: Differences in Learning Across the Lifespan Emerge via Resource-Rational Computations
div.p: Rasmus Bruckner 1,2,3,* , Matthew R. Nassar 4,5 , Shu-Chen Li 6,7 , Ben Eppinger Across both experiments, participants completed the Identical Picture test measuring processing speed and the Spot-a-Word test measuring verbal knowledge . As detailed below, our results are in line with previous studies showing age-related declines in fluid abilities and age-related increases in crystallized abilities (Li et al., 2004).

In the first experiment ( Fig. S1a), an ANOVA showed significantly different Identical Picture scores between the age groups (H = 74.034, p < 0.001). Children (median = 20.0, IQR 18.0 to 22.0) had significantly lower scores compared to adolescents (median = 29.0, IQR 27.0 to 32.0; u = 90.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.483) and younger adults (median = 32.0, IQR 29.0 to 36.25; u = 31.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.653) but not compared to older adults (median = 20.0, IQR 17.5 to 24.0; u = 564.0, p = 0.873; R 2 = 0.0). Adolescents had significantly higher scores compared with older adults (u = 914.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.468) but not compared to younger adults (u = 336.0, p = 0.064; R 2 = 0.056). Finally, younger adults had significantly higher scores compared to older adults (u = 1068.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.606).

Regarding the Spot-a-Word test in the first experiment ( Fig. S1b), an ANOVA yielded significant differences across the age groups (H = 82.768, p < 0.001). Scores of children (median = 3.0, IQR 1.0 to 6.0) were significantly lower compared to adolescents (median = 13.0, IQR 12.0 to 17.0; u = 102.5, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.453), younger adults (median = 20.5, IQR 16.75 to 25.0; u = 6.5, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.719), and older adults (median = 24.0, IQR 16.5 to 30.0; u = 4.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.727). Adolescents had significantly lower scores compared to younger adults (u = 176.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.283) and older adults (u = 147.5, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.367). Finally, the test yielded a significant difference between younger and older adults (u = 403.0, p = 0.049; R 2 = 0.058).

In the follow-up experiment (Fig. S1c), an ANOVA indicated significantly different Identical Picture scores (H = 55.247, p < 0.001). Children (median = 18.0, IQR 16.5 to 21.0) had significantly lower scores compared to younger adults (median = 33.0, IQR 31.0 to 35.0; u = 0.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.727) but not compared to older adults (median = 20.0, IQR 17.0 to 23.75; u = 382.0, p = 0.057; R 2 = 0.055). Finally, younger adults had significantly higher scores than older adults (u = 846.5, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.707).

Concerning the Spot-a-Word test in the follow-up experiment (Fig. S1d), the age groups had significantly different scores as well (H = 50.842, p < 0.001). Children's scores (median = 7.0, IQR 4.5 to 12.0) were significantly lower compared to younger adults (median = 20.0, IQR 19.0 to 25.0; u = 128.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.325) and compared to older adults (median = 32.0, IQR

div.head: Task instructions
div.p: Before completing the experimental task, participants were instructed verbally and using written material on the computer screen. We built up the helicopter cover story step-by-step, with practice blocks in between. Every practice phase consisted of a low-and high-variability block. In the first practice phase, the helicopter was always visible. To ensure that participants understood that the helicopter was the best predictor of the outcomes, we used a response criterion that required participants to put their bucket ten times exactly underneath the visible helicopter. These blocks either stopped after the criterion was reached or after a maximum of 80 trials. In the second practice phase, clouds covered the helicopter, and participants had to infer its location based on the outcomes. Occasionally, the helicopter was visible during catch trials, and participants could use this information for learning. These blocks consisted of 50 trials and were the same as in the real experiment. After the practice session, we emphasized again that participants would earn money for their collected points. To test whether children and older adults can perform the task well without ambiguity about the helicopter location (catch trials), we compared estimation errors between catch trials and regular trials (with hidden helicopter). In the first experiment, all age groups showed significantly lower estimation errors on catch trials than on regular trials (Fig. S2a). In children, median = -4.189, IQR = -6.547 to -1.301, w = 34.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.588. In adolescents, median = -4.494, IQR = -5.216 to -2.418, w = 5.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.728. In younger adults, median = -3.393, IQR = -5.376 to -1.796, w = 1.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.756. Finally, in older adults, median = -2.842, IQR = -4.727 to -0.405, w = 99.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.358. The ANOVA did not yield significant differences between the groups (H = 5.7, p = 0.127), suggesting comparable performance levels.

div.head: Catch-trial control analysis
div.p: Similarly, in the follow-up experiment, all age groups showed lower estimation errors on catch trials (Fig. S2b). In children, median = -4.31, IQR = -6.811 to -2.618, w = 13.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.684. In younger adults, median = -4.378, IQR = -6.522 to -2.823, w = 10.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.673. In older adults, median = -4.424, IQR = -6.903 to -0.911, w = 74.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.429. The ANOVA did not yield significant differences between the groups (H = 0.532, p = 0.766), suggesting similar performance levels as well.

Taken together, these results indicate that age groups had similar abilities to improve their performance based on explicit information about the mean of the outcome-generating distribution. This suggests a comparable understanding of the task instructions, similar motivation, and necessary visual and motor capabilities. According to Wilcoxon sign-rank tests, no age group showed a significant perseverationprobability difference between the high-and low-reward condition (Fig. S3a). In children, median = 0.007, IQR -0.022 to 0.03, w = 214.0, p = 0.505, R 2 = 0.014. In younger adults, median = 0.004, IQR -0.017 to 0.022, w = 144.0, p = 0.619, R 2 = 0.01. In older adults, median = -0.004, IQR -0.015 to 0.028, w = 291.0, p = 0.912, R 2 = 0.0. Because our primary interest in the follow-up experiment was to explore which task manipulations were associated with decreased perseveration, we did not analyze the difference between high-and low-incentive trials in detail but focused on the difference between the standard and anchoring condition. For the sake of completeness, we here provide the age-related estimation-error differences between the high-and low-reward trials (Fig. S3b). In all age groups, Wilcoxon sign-rank tests yielded a significant estimation-error difference between the high-and low-reward condition (children: median = 1.177, IQR 0.304 to 2.406, w = 57.0, p < 0.001; younger adults: median = 1.289, IQR 0.967 to 2.145, w = 25.0, p < 0.001; older adults: median = 1.069, IQR 0.508 to 2.032, w = 37.0, p < 0.001).

div.head: Supplementary results follow-up experiment
div.p: To examine if these performance differences might be driven by differences in learning rates, we compared average learning rates between conditions. However, in all age groups, the Wilcoxon sign-rank tests yielded insignificant differences. In children, median = 0.01, IQR -0.034 to 0.054; w = 220.0, p = 0.583; R 2 = 0.01. In younger adults, median = -0.028, IQR -0.056 to 0.017; w = 95.0, p = 0.069; R 2 = 0.132. In older adults, median = 0.008, IQR -0.026 to 0.031, w = 255.0, p = 0.467; R 2 = 0.016.

We next provide additional details on the differences in the estimated perseveration probabilities in the standard compared to the anchoring condition. According to Wilcoxon sign-rank tests, children (median = -0.45, IQR -0.592 to -0.335, w = 0.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.762), younger adults (median = -0.19, IQR -0.37 to -0.15, w = 0.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.765), and older adults (median = -0.48, IQR -0.576 to -0.352, w = 0.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.761) perseverated significantly less in the anchoring condition compared to the standard condition (Fig. S3c).

Moreover, children (median = 3.671, IQR 0.622 to 4.774, w = 72.0, p = 0.001, R 2 = 0.384) and older adults (median = 3.636, IQR 1.312 to 8.229, w = 42.0, p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.561) showed higher estimation errors in the anchoring condition compared with the standard condition. In younger adults, this test did not yield a significant estimation-error difference between the conditions (median = 0.107, IQR -0.773 to 1.088, w = 139.0, p = 0.527, R 2 = 0.016) (Fig. S3d).

Finally, we zoomed into the perseveration trials in the anchoring condition by dividing the trials into "edge" and regular trials. Edge trials reflect trials in which the starting position of the bucket was either z t = 0 (left edge of the screen) or z t = 300 (right edge of the screen). On these trials, the anchoring effect could be different from regular trials because the shift in the location could not affect the starting position beyond the edge. As shown in Fig. S3e, perseveration was practically absent in regular trials and thus primarily occurred on edge trials, suggesting that the few cases of perseveration (c.f. Fig. S3c, anchoring condition) were driven by edge trials in which the anchoring effect was truncated. A similar result was observed for motor perseveration trials (Fig. S3f). Motor perseveration refers to the prediction in the initial bucket location (see SM Data preprocessing), which was absent in regular trials but occasionally took place on edge trials. Together, these results support the conclusion that our anchoring manipulation strongly reduced the perseverative behavior of our participants.

div.head: Average learning rate follow-up experiment
div.p: We tested which factors determined participants' belief updates in the follow-up experiment. Similar to the first experiment, we analyzed average learning rates across all trials, indicating to which extent prediction errors influenced the belief update on average. The ANOVA showed that learning rates were significantly different between the age groups (H = 21.951, p < 0.001). The post-hoc tests indicated significantly lower learning rates in children (median = 0.73, IQR 0.65 to 0.838) compared to younger adults (median = 0.884, IQR 0.86 to 0.923; u = 131.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.318) but not compared to older adults (median = 0.772, IQR 0.699 to 0.854; u = 466.0, p = 0.427; R 2 = 0.01). Similarly, younger adults had significantly higher learning rates compared to older adults (u = 683.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.264). As in the first experiment, these results show that children and older adults use lower learning rates than younger adults, i.e., they use prediction errors to a lesser degree for updating their beliefs about the helicopter. Figure S4. Mixture model. To account for age-related differences in perseveration within our model, the model contained a perseveration component that allowed for a better explanation of participant data than a control model without perseveration. a In our task, perseveration can computationally be described as a learning rate αt = 0, which leads the model to ignore the prediction error and, consequently, to an exact repetition of the previous prediction. b We modeled the contribution of this perseveration component (perseveration probability) as a function of the predicted update of the reduced Bayesian model. In effect, the model predicted a higher perseveration probability for smaller prediction errors. Figure S5. Hypothetical and estimated learning deficits resulting from specific deviations from the reduced Bayesian learning model. a-c The reduced Bayesian model (RBM) uses a high learning rate in response to large prediction errors that are more likely due to change points. In the range of small prediction errors more likely due to variability, it uses a lower learning rate to average out the variability in the outcomes. We hypothesized that learning deficits might stem from specific deviations from the learning-rate computations of the reduced Bayesian model, including an underestimation of uncertainty, lower surprise sensitivity, and a subjectively high hazard rate (Biased). a An underestimation of uncertainty leads to a specific learning deficit in the range of small prediction errors unlikely to be due to change points. That is, the model has a reduced ability to average out the variability in the outcomes. b Insensitivity to surprise leads to a learning deficit in the range of large prediction errors that are likely to be due to change points. Consequently, the model has a reduced ability to respond to change points appropriately. d The hazard rate reflects the model's assumed frequency of change points. A subjectively higher hazard rate, i.e., overestimating how often change points occur, is associated with higher learning rates in the range of small and intermediate prediction errors. d-f Estimated parameters reflecting d uncertainty underestimation, e surprise sensitivity, and f subjective hazard rate for children (CH), adolescents (AD), younger adults (YA), and older adults (OA).

To better understand the computational underpinnings of differences in learning, we analyzed trial-by-trial dynamics of learning-rate adjustments in the different age groups using the mixture model. The uncertainty-underestimation parameter reflects the extent to which participants underestimate uncertainty during learning. Higher uncertainty-underestimation parameters lead to lower learning rates in the range of small prediction errors, which are most likely due to environmental variability (Fig. S5a). The mostly positive parameter estimates reflecting uncertainty underestimation shown in Fig. S5d suggest that all age groups tended to underestimate uncertainty because a full consideration of uncertainty is indicated with an uncertainty-underestimation parameter equal to 0. We next used an ANOVA to compare uncertainty underestimation across the four age groups. The test yielded significant parameter differences between the age groups (H = 8.836, p = 0.032). Older adults (median = 3.879, IQR 2.639 to 4.478) showed significantly higher uncertainty underestimation compared to adolescents (median = 2.443, IQR 1.411 to 4.271; u = 358.0, p = 0.044; R 2 = 0.063) and compared to younger adults (median = 2.524, IQR 1.49 to 4.214; u = 348.0, p = 0.008; R 2 = 0.105). That is, in line with our previous work, the results suggest reduced uncertainty-driven learning in older adults compared to their younger counterparts. However, the test did not yield a significant difference between children (median = 3.445, IQR 2.184 to 4.423) compared to adolescents (u = 568.0, p = 0.209; R 2 = 0.025), younger adults (u = 668.0, p = 0.067; R 2 = 0.052), and older adults (u = 503.0, p = 0.364; R 2 = 0.012). The test did not show a significant difference between adolescents and younger adults (u = 506.0, p = 0.549; R 2 = 0.006).

The surprise-sensitivity parameter indicates the influence of change-point probability on the learning rate. Lower surprise sensitivity reflects lower learning rates in the range of large prediction errors that are most likely due to change points (Fig. S5b). The surprise-sensitivity estimates shown in Fig. S5e suggest that all age groups considered change-point probability, albeit not as much as the reduced Bayesian model, which has a surprise sensitivity of 1. Moreover, the ANOVA indicated significantly different median surprise-sensitivity parameters between the age groups (H = 10.195, p = 0.017). Younger adults (median = 0.312, IQR 0.177 to 0.48) showed significantly higher surprise sensitivity compared to children (median = 0.11, IQR 0.052 to 0.339; u = 324.0, p = 0.008; R 2 = 0.11) and compared to older adults (median = 0.198, IQR 0.081 to 0.294; u = 762.0, p = 0.011; R 2 = 0.095). The test did not yield a significant difference between children and adolescents (median = 0.206, IQR 0.129 to 0.35; u = 349.5, p = 0.07; R 2 = 0.053), children and older adults (u = 515.5, p = 0.45; R 2 = 0.008), adolescents and younger adults (u = 385.0, p = 0.257; R 2 = 0.021), and between adolescents and older adults (u = 596.5, p = 0.233; R 2 = 0.022).

The hazard-rate parameter models assumptions about the frequency of change points. A higher hazard rate reflects the assumption that change points occur more frequently in the task and leads to higher levels of change-point probability and, thus, higher learning rates for small and intermediate prediction errors (Fig. S5c). The true but unknown hazard rate was approximately 0.1, i.e., the hazard-rate parameter estimates shown in Fig. S5f suggest that most participants overestimated the frequency of change points in the task. However, the ANOVA (H = 2.573, p = 0.462) did not yield significant hazard-rate parameter differences between children (median = 0.499, IQR 0.372 to 0.553), adolescents (median = 0.504, IQR 0.354 to 0.612), younger adults (median = 0.448, IQR 0.29 to 0.595), and older adults (median = 0.49, IQR 0.454 to 0.58). Here we also present the additionally estimated parameters of the mixture model. The motornoise parameter o 0 modeled prediction noise that was independent of the update magnitude (Fig. S6a). An ANOVA yielded a significant difference between the groups (H = 10.661, p = 0.014). The test showed significantly lower motor noise in younger adults (median = 2.591, IQR 1.328 to 4.203) compared to children (median = 4.82, IQR 3.214 to 6.465; u = 752.5, p = 0.003; R 2 = 0.133), adolescents (median = 4.631, IQR 2.099 to 6.794; u = 623.5, p = 0.022; R 2 = 0.086), and older adults (median = 3.868, IQR 2.61 to 5.129; u = 395.5, p = 0.04; R 2 = 0.063). The test did not yield a significant difference between children and adolescents (u = 494.0, p = 0.832; R 2 = 0.001), children and older adults (u = 690.5, p = 0.167; R 2 = 0.028), and adolescents and older adults (u = 585.5, p = 0.296; R 2 = 0.017).

The learning-rate noise parameter o 1 modeled prediction noise depending on the update magnitude (Fig. S6b). The ANOVA did not indicate significant differences between children (median = 0.187, IQR 0.115 to 0.234), adolescents (median = 0.141, IQR 0.075 to 0.222), younger adults (median = 0.197, IQR 0.142 to 0.365), and older adults (median = 0.167, IQR 0.088 to 0.252) (H = 6.785, p = 0.079).

The intercept parameter b 0 of the logistic function was indicative of perseveration ( Fig. S6c). An ANOVA yielded significant median intercept differences between the age groups (H = 29.834, p < 0.001). Post-hoc tests indicated a significant difference between children (median = 12.117, IQR 5.114 to 24.347) and adolescents (median = 0.828, IQR -12.628 to 4.456; u = 773.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.277), children and younger adults (median = 0.856, IQR -2.886 to 3.695; u = 849.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.272), children and older adults (median = 7.49, IQR 4.035 to 11.389; u = 745.5, p = 0.04; R 2 = 0.062), adolescents and older adults (u = 276.0, p = 0.002; R 2 = 0.152), younger adults and older adults (u = 301.0, p = 0.001; R 2 = 0.157), but not between adolescents and younger adults (u = 454.0, p = 0.891; R 2 = 0.0).

Perseveration was also reflected in the slope parameter b 1 of the logistic function (Fig. S6d). An ANOVA did not yield significant median slope differences between the age groups (H = 7.068, p = 0.07). In children, median = -0.167, IQR -0.248 to -0.092. In adolescents, median = -0.274, IQR -0.443 to -0.147. In younger adults, median = -0.256, IQR -0.594 to -0.14. In older adults, median = -0.195, IQR -0.328 to -0.114. The combination of the intercept and slope parameters is reflected in higher perseveration probabilities in children and older adults, which are especially evident in the range of small and intermediate updates (Fig. 3d).

The reward-bias parameter q modeled the influence of high versus low reward on the learning rate (Fig. S6e). In children, median = 0.042, IQR 0.006 to 0.104. In adolescents, median = 0.058, IQR -0.003 to 0.107. In younger adults, median = 0.026, IQR 0.002 to 0.065. In older adults, median = 0.025, IQR -0.022 to 0.05. An ANOVA did not yield a significant difference between the age groups (H = 6.288, p = 0.098).

Finally, the catch-trial parameter σ H modeled the influence of catch trials on the update magnitude ( Fig. S6f) In children,median = 13.53,IQR 8.774 to 24.748. In adolescents,median = 9.508,IQR 5.417 to 22.161. In younger adults,median = 13.082,IQR 8.779 to 20.771. In older adults,median = 10.963,IQR 5.228 to 26.513. An ANOVA did not yield significant differences between the age groups (H = 0.873, p = 0.832). In our previous study, we focused on uncertainty underestimation in older compared to younger adults using a model without perseveration component . To examine if the age-related differences in uncertainty underestimation might be more clearly pronounced in a model without perseveration, we here additionally examined uncertainty underestimation in our control model. In Fig. S7, we show the parameter estimates of the control model without perseveration, which fit the data worse compared to the mixture model that captured perseveration (see Model comparison). To test if the uncertainty-underestimation parameters in this model were different between the age groups, we also applied an ANOVA (H = 14.409, p = 0.002). Post-hoc tests showed a significant difference between children (median = 4.238, IQR 2.753 to 6.361) and adolescents (median = 2.456, IQR 1.692 to 3.728; u = 675.0, p = 0.006; R 2 = 0.123), children and younger adults (median = 3.108, IQR 1.972 to 4.167; u = 701.0, p = 0.024; R 2 = 0.079), adolescents and older adults (median = 3.732, IQR 2.797 to 5.16; u = 277.0, p = 0.002; R 2 = 0.15), and younger and older adults (u = 369.0, p = 0.017; R 2 = 0.085). The test did not yield a significant difference between children and older adults (u = 604.0, p = 0.75; R 2 = 0.001), and adolescents and younger adults (u = 414.0, p = 0.475; R 2 = 0.008).

div.head: Control model
div.p: These results suggest that the perseveration component of our best-fitting model partly captures variance that the uncertainty-underestimation parameter captures in the control model without perseveration. Both uncertainty underestimation and perseveration lead to an underadjustment of predictions. Uncertainty underestimation leads to an update that is smaller than prescribed by the normative version of the reduced Bayesian model, while perseveration leads to a no-update altogether. Moreover, both effects occur primarily after small to intermediate prediction errors. To test this idea more directly, we next simulated data based on the model that included the perseveration component. The parameter values of the uncertaintyunderestimation parameter were 0 (indicating no underestimation) for all simulated partici-pants, and all other values corresponded to the model-based estimates obtained from model fitting (including age-related difference in preservation). We then fit the control model without perseveration component to this simulated data set and, in line with our argument, found that uncertainty underestimation was larger in simulated children and older adults compared to the other two groups (Fig. S8). Uncertainty Underestimation Figure S8. Uncertainty underestimation in simulation-based control analysis. We examined whether perseveration can be attributed to uncertainty underestimation in a control model that does not include the perseveration component. We first performed a simulation study using the reduced Bayesian model with perseveration, where the parameter values were based on the empirical, model-based estimates. Therefore, perseveration probability was comparable between the simulated and empirical data sets (including the age-related differences with more perseveration in children and older adults). Crucially, in all simulations, we set the uncertainty-underestimation parameter to zero. We then fit the control model to the simulated data to examine whether the uncertainty-underestimation parameter picks up variance that is due to perseveration. The uncertainty-underestimation parameters are higher in simulated children and older adults, although the ground-truth parameters were zero, indicating that perseveration (which was higher in simulated children and older adults) can give rise to the appearance of uncertainty underestimation when perseveration is not modeled explicitly. We used the cumulated Bayesian information criterion (BIC; and the corresponding protected exceedance probabilities for model comparison (see Model comparison). Here, higher BIC values indicate a better model fit (Fig. S9a). We used protected exceedance probabilities for model comparison on the group level, which indicates the probability that a particular model is more likely than any other model of the model space (Fig. S9b). Together, this indicated that in each age group, the mixture model fits the data better than the reduced Bayesian model without perseveration. We finally counted the number of participants, in which the mixture model fits the data better than the reduced Bayesian model without perseveration. This indicated that in 121 out of 129 participants, the model comparison favored the mixture model. To confirm that age-related differences in anchoring capture performance differences beyond the computational factors of our model, we added an anchoring-bias parameter. As illustrated in Fig. 4b, in this extended version, the model's prediction of the next outcome was biased towards the anchor. This bias was governed by an additional free parameter, where higher parameter values indicate a stronger bias (Fig. S10i). According to an ANOVA, the parameters were significantly different between the age groups (H = 27.835, p < 0.001). Post-hoc tests indicated a significant difference between children (median = 0.162, IQR 0.087 to 0.277) and younger adults (median = 0.047, IQR 0.019 to 0.085; u = 583.0, p = 0.001; R 2 = 0.184), children and older adults (median = 0.302, IQR 0.133 to 0.426; u = 323.0, p = 0.008; R 2 = 0.11), and between younger and older adults (u = 101.0, p < 0.001; R 2 = 0.417).

div.head: Supplementary modeling results follow-up experiment
div.p: Moreover, an ANOVA yielded a significantly different motor-noise parameter o 0 across the age groups (H = 9.132, p = 0.01; Fig. S10a). Children (median = 8.156, IQR 6.245 to 9.711) showed significantly higher motor noise compared to younger adults (median = 5.77, IQR 4.292 to 7.046; u = 565.0, p = 0.003; R 2 = 0.152), but not compared to older adults (median = 6.72, IQR 4.819 to 8.572; u = 664.5, p = 0.071; R 2 = 0.05). The test did not yield a significant difference between younger and older adults (u = 330.0, p = 0.147; R 2 = 0.036).

An ANOVA yielded a significantly different learning-rate noise parameter o 1 between the age groups (H = 6.659, p = 0.036). Post-hoc tests showed a significant difference between children (median = 0.198, IQR 0.107 to 0.31) and younger adults (median = 0.097, IQR 0.073 to 0.178; u = 527.5, p = 0.021; R 2 = 0.094) and between younger adults and older adults (median = 0.171, IQR 0.129 to 0.271; u = 282.0, p = 0.029; R 2 = 0.081). The test did not indicate a significant difference between children and older adults (u = 564.0, p = 0.632; R 2 = 0.004) (Fig. S10b).

The ANOVA also yielded a significant age-related difference in the intercept parameter b 0 of the logistic function (H = 11.163, p = 0.004). Follow-up tests indicated a significant difference between children (median = 7.704, IQR 5.083 to 11.877) and younger adults (median = 3.015, IQR 0.749 to 7.464; u = 566.0, p = 0.003; R 2 = 0.154) and between younger and older adults (median = 6.547, IQR 4.283 to 8.789; u = 243.0, p = 0.005; R 2 = 0.131). The test did not indicate a significant difference between children and older adults (u = 603.0, p = 0.321; R 2 = 0.015) (Fig. S10c).

With respect to the slope of the logistic function b 1 , an ANOVA showed significant differences between the age groups (H = 6.532, p = 0.038). Children (median = -0.314, IQR -0.454 to -0.213) had significantly higher slopes than older adults (median = -0.542, IQR -0.813 to -0.327; u = 684.0, p = 0.04; R 2 = 0.065). Younger adults (median = -0.311, IQR -0.404 to -0.226) had significantly higher slopes than older adults (u = 575.0, p = 0.022; R 2 = 0.089). Finally, the slopes of children and younger adults were not significantly different (u = 404.0, p = 0.792; R 2 = 0.001) (Fig. S10d).

For the uncertainty-underestimation parameter u, an ANOVA did not indicate significant differences between the age groups (H = 3.847, p = 0.146). In children, median = 3.102, IQR 2.204 to 4.483. In younger adults, median = 2.401, IQR 0.963 to 3.924. In older adults, median = 3.456, IQR 2.282 to 4.77 (Fig. S10e).

Moreover, the test yielded a significant difference in the surprise-sensitivity parameter s (H = 10.269, p = 0.006). Post-hoc tests indicated a significant difference between children (median = 0.077, IQR 0.022 to 0.346) and older adults (median = 0.463, IQR 0.084 to 0.64; u = 312.5, p = 0.005; R 2 = 0.122) and between younger adults (median = 0.099, IQR 0.058 to 0.203) and older adults (u = 261.0, p = 0.012; R 2 = 0.107). The test did not yield a significant difference between children and younger adults (u = 336.0, p = 0.4; R 2 = 0.013) (Fig. S10f).

Next, the test yielded a significant age-related difference in the hazard-rate parameter h (H = 6.851, p = 0.033) (Fig. S10g). Children (median = 0.52, IQR 0.475 to 0.543) had significantly lower hazard-rate parameters compared to younger adults (median = 0.628, IQR 0.465 to 0.718; u = 261.0, p = 0.038; R 2 = 0.077) but not compared to older adults (median = 0.52, IQR 0.423 to 0.579; u = 539.0, p = 0.88; R 2 = 0.0). Younger adults had significantly higher hazard-rate parameters compared to older adults (u = 588.0, p = 0.013; R 2 = 0.105).

Finally, the ANOVA did not yield a significant age-related difference in the catch-trial parameter σ H (H = 2.008, p = 0.366) between children (median = 24.305, IQR 13.135 to 31.358), younger adults (median = 18.964, IQR 6.656 to 32.0) and older adults (median = 26.98, IQR 18.673 to 32.0) (Fig. S10h). To test if the parameters of the mixture model between the reduced Bayesian model and the perseveration model can accurately be estimated, we conducted a parameter-recovery study. We used randomly selected parameters during the simulations to examine if a broad range of parameter combinations is recoverable. These parameters were based on the participants' empirical parameter distributions and additionally constrained between the approximate minimum and maximum empirical parameter estimates. The parameter-recovery results for the first (Fig. S11) and follow-up experiment (Fig. S12) suggest that parameters can sufficiently be estimated except for the catch-trial parameter, which was often estimated at the upper boundary. This result indicates that the empirical results regarding catch trials should be cautiously treated. To test whether the mixture model can capture age differences in perseveration and estimation errors, we simulated learning behavior for each age group. Each dot represents a simulated participant, and the boxplots show the empirical data for comparison. The results suggest that the mixture model qualitatively captures the pattern of a perseveration and b estimation errors across the age groups. c To test whether perseveration might contribute to age-related performance differences, we simulated learning behavior and set the perseveration probabilities to zero in all cases. d The simulation results suggest that, without perseveration, the four age groups would perform at similar levels.

div.head: First experiment
div.p: One potential concern with using computational models as data-analytic tools is that although they make quantitative predictions of the data, they might fail to reproduce the observed data in simulations qualitatively (Palminteri, Wyart, & Koechlin, 2017). We used the estimated mixture model to simulate learning behavior to test if our model-based analyses accurately captured participants' behavior. First, to test if the estimated reduced Bayesian model with an additional perseveration component qualitatively reproduces participant behavior, we applied it to the same sequence of data as experienced by our participants. To obtain smoother simulation results, we repeated this procedure across three cycles. The comparison between empirical and simulated data is shown in Fig. S13a (perseveration probability) and Fig. S13b (estimation errors). In addition, as shown in Fig. S13c,d, we also used simulations to explore if the reduced Bayesian model without perseveration would predict similar performance levels between the age groups. Here, we conducted the simulations as described above but adjusted the parameters such that perseveration probability was approximately equal to zero. These results suggested similar performance levels and motivated our follow-up experiment that tested if age-related performance differences can be eliminated with manipulations to reduce perseveration.

div.head: Follow-up experiment
div.p: As in our model-validation analyses of the first experiment, we conducted the simulations with the estimated parameters and the same outcomes observed by our participants. These simulations revealed that the simulated perseveration ( Fig. S14a) and estimation-error ( Fig. S14b) differences qualitatively matched our empirically obtained results, which suggests that our computational model accurately captured participants' behavior. We also applied a robust linear regression model with age group
div.formula: d i = β 0 + β 1p (n) i + β ya 2 g i + β ch 2 g i + β ya 3p (n)g i + β ch 3p (n)g i(30)
div.p: where i denotes the subject and g i denotes age group that we coded as dummy variable with older adults as reference category. The model thus contained an additional main effect of age group with regression weight β 2 and an interaction between age group and perseveration probability with regression weight β 3 . This model revealed a significant main effect of perseveration probability β 1 = 0.8617 (z = 4.874, p < 0.001), and a significant interaction between perseveration probability and the level of younger adults of the age group variable β ya 3 = −0.8372 (z = −3.286, p = 0.001) and the level of children β ch 3 = −0.4635 (z = −2.173, p = 0.03). All other parameters were not significant: β 0 = −0.1269 (z = −1.453, p = 0.146), β ya 2 = 0.1769 (z = 1.699, p = 0.089), β ch 2 = 0.1213 (z = 1.146, p = 0.252). The coefficient of determination of the model was R 2 = 0.464. Hence, this robust regression with age group suggests that the anchoring bias is systematically related to perseveration and that this relationship is weaker in younger adults and children compared to older adults. For the predicted values according to this model, see To validate the sampling model, we compared the computational variables between the sampling and the reduced Bayesian model. To approximate optimal inference, we used a large number of samples (2000 samples) without applying the stopping criterion. The comparison shows that the trial-by-trial beliefs, prediction errors, relative uncertainty, and change-point probability variables are similar between the two models. This illustrates that the sampling model can closely approximate near-optimal Bayesian inference if a sufficient number of samples is drawn. Figure S19. Joint effect of chunk size and criterion parameter on perseveration probability and anchoring bias. We illustrate the effects of varying parameter values to show how different parameter settings impact perseveration and anchoring. In particular, the plot demonstrates how the criterion parameter influences the biases under three different chunk-size settings. These simulation results reveal a general trend where both perseveration and anchoring tend to increase as the criterion values become larger. Moreover, the examples demonstrate that the effects of the parameters interact to some extent. Illustration of a perseveration and b anchoring for lower chunk-size parameters similar to values in children and older adults (chunk size = 1). Here, perseveration and the anchoring bias increase as a function of a larger criterion. When chunk size is larger (chunk size = 3), c perseveration and d anchoring increase as a function of the criterion, but the overall magnitude of the biases is lower. e Finally, when chunk size is more young-adult-like (chunk size = 15), perseveration still increases, f but the anchoring bias almost remains constant. This corresponds to a floor effect, where the larger number of samples overwrites the impact of the anchor. Consequently, these examples suggest a diminishing correlation between perseveration and anchoring as the chunk-size parameter increases. Figure S20. Resource-only model. The resource-only model assumed that age groups only differ in their cognitive resources. It allowed us to test if a model without a dynamic stopping criterion captures the behavioral results similar to the resource-rational sampling model. We first simulated data with baseline parameter settings leading to a moderate perseveration, b low estimation errors, and c a small anchoring bias. We then chose "perseveration" parameter values that d yielded age-related differences in perseverative behavior. However, these parameter values led to e strongly overestimated estimation errors and f anchoring biases. In opposition to these parameter settings, the "anchoring" parameters g did not capture perseveration but instead h age-differences in estimation errors and i the anchoring bias. Together, these results suggest that a dynamic stopping criterion, like in the resource-rational sampling model, is necessary to explain our results.

div.head: Resource-only model
div.p: We performed a simulation study with the resource-only model to examine whether an alternative sampling model in which age groups only differ in their cognitive resources could explain our results. This model lacked a dynamic stopping criterion and instead invested a fixed amount of resources on each trial. As such, a sampling model without a dynamic stopping criterion does not naturally show perseverative behavior. Still, to test the model under fair conditions (in favor of the resource-only model), we added the logistic function explained above (Evaluation and estimation) with fixed parameters that yielded perseverative behavior for smaller prediction errors (intercept β 0 = 0.85, slope β 1 = −0.25). We first simulated data with a baseline model, which generated a sufficient amount of samples to achieve high task performance (100 samples).

In particular, the model showed moderate perseveration due to the logistic function ( Fig. S20a), low estimation errors in both the standard and anchoring condition (Fig. S20b), as well as a minor anchoring bias (Fig. S20c).

We next tried to model age-related differences in perseveration and anchoring based on common parameter settings. When we assumed a very low number of samples in children and older adults (2 samples) and more samples in younger adults (10 samples), the simulations suggested perseveration differences between the groups (Fig. S20d). However, these parameter settings clearly overestimated estimation errors and the anchoring bias. Conversely, assuming more samples (children and older adults 20 samples, younger adults 50 samples) led to more realistic estimation errors and anchoring biases but underestimated age-related perseveration differences. Therefore, the resource-only control model did not offer a unifying explanation for the observed biases across the lifespan. As such, it suggests that a resource-rational stopping criterion, as proposed by our main sampling model, is necessary to capture age-related differences in perseveration and anchoring.

div.head: Motor model
div.p: To explore whether motor costs provide an alternative account of perseveration and anchoring, we developed a motor-control model. The motor model was based on the reduced Bayesian model and had additional motor costs associated with bucket adjustments. Larger updates of the bucket position were associated with higher motor costs. At the same time, the model considered "error" costs due to an under-adjustment of the bucket. Therefore, the model was confronted with a trade-off between motor and error costs. Not adjusting the bucket at all would minimize motor costs but would also be associated with high error costs. In contrast, updating the bucket optimally according to the reduced Bayesian model would minimize error costs but would be associated with higher motor cots. The model solved this trade-off by minimizing the combined costs (motor and error costs).

We first simulated data using a baseline model with parameter settings resembling the reduced Bayesian model ( Fig. S21a-d). This version of the model only considered error costs. Error costs were minimal in the location of the optimal belief (v l = 0.5, e v = 1.1, v m = 0.0, e m = 1.0, Fig. S21a). Therefore, the model showed approximately optimal belief updating. We ensured that perseveration did only rarely occur (logistic function parameters modeling perseveration were b 0 = 0.5 and b 1 = −5.0) and found that estimation errors were low and anchoring biases absent.

The next simulations included additional motor costs and indicated that the motor model did not provide a unifying explanation for perseveration and anchoring. Assuming extremely high motor costs, the model showed perseveration probabilities that differed between younger adults and children and older adults (children and older adults: v m = 0.75, e m = 1.2; younger adults v m = 0.5, e m = 1.0; Fig. S21e). However, the resulting estimation errors and anchoring biases were unrealistically high. Assuming lower motor costs allowed us to successfully capture differences in anchoring and estimation errors (children and older adults: v m = 0.1, e m = 1.4; younger adults v m = 0.1, e m = 1.0; Fig. S21i). However, these parameter settings strongly underestimated perseveration in all age groups. Taken together, while the motor model can separately account for perseveration or anchoring, it cannot recover the two biases based on common parameter settings. Therefore, our control analyses do not support the idea that adding motor costs to the reduced Bayesian model provides an alternative explanation for perseveration and anchoring. Figure S21. Motor model. The motor model allowed us to test whether adding motor costs to the reduced Bayesian model could explain perseveration and anchoring from a perspective different from our sampling model. a A baseline model only considered error costs. Error costs were higher when the bucket was placed further away from the optimal location. This version resembled the reduced Bayesian model. b The baseline model perseverated only rarely, c estimation errors were low, and d the model did not show systematic anchoring biases. e The "perseveration" version of the motor model had extremely high motor costs (and the same error costs as the baseline model). The three lines only reflect the parameters of simulated children and older adults. f Due to the high motor costs, particularly simulated children and older adults perseverated more frequently than younger adults. g However, estimation errors were strongly overestimated, and h anchoring biases showed a ceiling effect. i In contrast, the "anchoring" version had lower motor costs (and the same error costs as before). The three lines only reflect the parameters of simulated children and older adults. j Due to the lower motor costs, perseveration was underestimated. k,l However, in this case, estimation errors and anchoring biases were closer to the empirical data. Taken together, the results show that our motor model does not explain our results convincingly.

To keep track of this mixture distribution over many trials, message-passing algorithms that consider all possible mixtures between change-point and no-change-point trials have been applied in previous work . However, these methods require many costly computations, which arguably go beyond human-level capacities . Therefore, Nassar and colleagues proposed a reduced Bayesian model that requires fewer computations and shares the core assumptions of the optimal Bayesian solution.

div.head: Approximate inference
div.p: The reduced Bayesian model approximates the mixture over all combinations of no-change-point and change-point trials with a Gaussian distribution with a similar mean and variance as the mixture distribution computed in optimal Bayesian inference. Notably, the reduced model also considers the scenario of "no change point" and "change point"; however, this only concerns the current trial t instead of all trials 1 : t.

We first show the derivation of the mixture component that assumes the absence of a change point . In the absence of change points, one can sequentially update a conjugate Gaussian distribution over the mean of the outcome-generating Gaussian distribution according to

Next, we consider the case that a change point occurred. Recall that a change point renders the past irrelevant, and therefore, under the assumption of a flat prior expectation over the parameter, the best prediction is the most recent outcome x t .
To appropriately weight these two mixture components, the reduced Bayesian model computes change-point probability ω t , defined as

div.head: Catch-trial derivations
div.p: On catch trials, we assumed that the provided helicopter cue that was centered on the true mean was perceived as an ambiguous cue that corresponded to a Gaussian probability density function (PDF) where the mean corresponded to the true helicopter location and the variance that expressed the reliability of the cue was assumed to be different between participants. In effect, the updated mean and variance followed from the multiplication of the Gaussian PDF over the learned helicopter location based on the history of outcomes and the Gaussian PDF over the presented helicopter position, where the covariance between the two distributions corresponds to
and the mean corresponds to
